The main chance of a ‘yes’ is if Hunt steps down.  But two factors make this less likely so I am reducing from 12%. 1) The race seems to be tightening. There is not a lot of polling but:  “A Survation poll of Conservative voters showed Johnson’s lead over Hunt had halved from 27 percentage points to just 11 since news of the altercation broke.”. Betting markets odds have similarly tightened. [1]  2) Hunt is not acting like someone who is going to back down. He has now called Johnson a coward for not agreeing to appear at the Sky debate and repeated his earlier remark that he would give Johnson “the fight of his life” [1]  And what would be the motive to step down for Hunt?
* Get on with the inevitable if he believes it’s better for the country. However, it’s not clear that a quicker election will make that a difference to Brexit given the Oct 31 deadline is so close anyway. 
* Avoid embarrassment from being trounced. However, it would also be also embarrassing to step down from a fight. Especially when he’d be confirming the media narrative about himself that he is the “preferred opponent”.
* Play nice with Johnson to get a cabinet seat (It’s hard for me to tell how much Hunt would want that) As we get closer to 1 July, the probability quickly reduces as there would be limited time for Johnson to assume the PM-ship even if Hunt would stand down. [1] https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-eu-leader-idUSKCN1TP0IA

There has been an argument put forward that no time can be lost replacing the PM because of the urgency with reopening negotiations with the EU. When the EU warned the UK not to waste the extra time they had (to 31st October) to leave the EU, they did not mean the UK had extra time to negotiate a new Withdrawal Agreement, they meant there was extra time for the UK Government to figure out how to get the WA that had already been agreed thru Parliament. As none of the candidates remaining have even mentioned the possibility of getting the current WA thru Parliament and are basing their tactics on forcing the EU to reopen the WA there is not really any rush to get the new PM in place, as the EU have made it clear that WA negotiations are over and the EU is busy sorting out who the EU Commission is going to be made up of from November. I doubt that Barnier would want to give the UK a Brexit renegotiation when he has no authority and he is busy trying to get a higher job.  
This confusion (ignorance) is typical of the UK's dealings with the EU, they seem to be incapable of understanding what those on the other side of the table will or can do, or what they want. Its very odd that the candidates for PM all claim to be expert negotiators but appear to have no idea how getting people to agree with you works. The same can be said of Trump of course (did I miss the Trump deals on the Middle East peace, made Iran behave, turned North Korea into a peaceful non-nuclear democracy, made America Great Again etc?)

The question is one if timing (before July 1). From Economist:
“This week Conservative MPs will winnow down to two the candidates to be their party leader—and thus Britain’s new prime minister. Boris Johnson begins the week as the overwhelming favourite but with his credibility damaged by his refusal to appear in a television debate on Sunday. Today Tory MPs hold closed-door hustings; tomorrow there will be a secret ballot to eliminate the least popular candidates (who need at least 33 votes to survive). The (probably five) remaining then appear in a second TV debate; this time Mr Johnson has deigned to take part. The prime-ministerial hopefuls have all shown an alarming tendency to embrace economic incompetence. Most are prepared to see the country crash out of the European Union without a deal. And they are proposing huge tax giveaways, often directly to their supporters. That is because the party’s 160,000 members—overwhelmingly white, male, affluent, Brexity and old—get the final say on whom to anoint.“

Absolutely will not be a prime minister from any other party. Outside chance of No 2 candidate forfeiting before members' vote, which could speed up the process so that it would be wrapped up before end of June. (Theresa May was elected without a members' vote.)

UPDATE 14.06.2019 Indeed, Boris Johnson’s lead (71 more votes than the second frontrunner) could result in a shorter election period than expected despite numerous candidates who run to become the next Prime Minister. In the next round, candidates with less than 33 votes will be excluded. Only Boris Johnson (114), Jeremy Hunt (43) and Michael Grove (37) exceeded this threshold in the first round. However, with 27 votes, Dominic Raab, might gather enough votes to exceed the threshold of the 2nd round. In this scenario, the remaining four candidates would enter into 2 other elections, in form of postal votes, until only 2 candidates remain. In the final election, the conservative party will decide who of these 2 candidates becomes the new Prime Minister.  The next rounds (non-postal votes) will take place at the 18th, 19th, and 20th of June. However, the last elections will be postal votes and, therefore, will likely require more time. The BBC states that “the winner of the contest to succeed Theresa May is expected to be announced in the week of 22 July” (BBC 2019).  As a result, this update will adjust the likelihood of “No” by +20%”.  Source:  -	BBC (2019): Boris Johnson tops first ballot in Tory leadership contest: https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-48624579

From the Economist:
Theresa May resigns today as Conservative Party leader, after failing to get her Brexit plan through Parliament. She will continue as Britain’s prime minister until a new party leader is chosen. The contest kicks off on June 10th. Eleven Tory MPs have already put themselves forward, but the party’s 1922 Committee, which supervises the race, says each must have the support of at least eight other lawmakers to stand. The parliamentary party then holds a series of votes to whittle the number down to two. In late June these two go to a postal ballot of 124,000 party members—who tend to be older and more vehement Brexiteers than the general population. That makes Boris Johnson, who says he is perfectly prepared to leave the European Union without a deal, the front-runner to inherit the prime ministership. Whoever wins will have little time to resolve Brexit, as the latest deadline for it is October 31st.“

On the 24th of May, British Prime Minister Theresa May has made a public resignation statement from her position as leader of the Conservative and Unionist Party, drawing her turbulent three-year premiership to a close. She will be stepping down from her role on the 7th of June. This creates the demand for another PM to be nominated as early as possible.  According to the BBC, the Conservative Party announced the likely timetable for the leadership contest was that nominations would close during the week beginning 10 June, with candidates whittled down by the end of the month. Furthermore, as the next general election in the United Kingdom is scheduled to be held on 5 May 2022 under the Fixed-term Parliaments Act 2011, it is required that the next person to take up the difficult job of delivering Brexit as Prime Minister will have to be a Tory, who are now holding the majority of the seats at Westminster.  Given these facts, I am 90% certain that someone new among the Tories will be appointed in the 30-day interval between her scheduled resignation and the forecasted date. EDIT: I have read the forecasts below and people seem to be concerned that the 30 days will not suffice. However, I would like to point out that David Cameron announced that he would resign the office of Prime Minister on 24 June and stepped down on the 13th of July, the same date as Theresa May assumed office, which is less than 3 weeks from the announced resignation under similar circumstances. Lastly, I'd like to remind us of the impatience of former foreign secretary Boris Johnson, seen as the front-runner to succeed May, who declared at a conference in Switzerland: "We will leave the EU on October 31, deal or no deal." https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-48395905

Indeed, sometimes uncertainties shape decisively the development of reality. May finally gave in and will resign as Conservative party leader at the 7th of June. The internal contest in the Conservative party, deciding who will succeed May, will start at the 10th of June. It seems unlikely that the new PM will be chosen quickly as there are several Tory politicians who already declared their interest and many more who might run for PM as well. Another factor which decreases the likelihood for a fast transition is the factional divide within the Conservative party (Soft vs. Hard Brexit supporters) as it further increases the effort it takes for one candidate to gather enough votes behind him/her. The BBC estimates that a new PM will be in place by end of July. Also, the Guardian states that the internal contest “is expected to last perhaps six weeks”.    However, there are also arguments in favour of a quick change which could result in a new conservative PM before the 1st of July. First of all, the transition from Cameron to May, after the former had stepped down, only took 17 days. This seems less likely if one considers the worsened party coherence due to the tough Brexit negotiations which also took place within the Conservative party. A new PM will need to convince his fellow party members that he/she is able to find a compromise. Something which seems like a Hercules task at this point. Another argument for a quick transition could be that the Conservatives will try to avoid instability in their party and in UK as well. A fast election process could display symbolic unity, something the party lacked during the last year. However, regarding the mentioned circumstances, this seems unlikely, too.  Considering all the stated arguments it is necessary to adjust the forecast accordingly. The option “No” will remain the most probable. Nevertheless, it will be reduced regarding that there are good arguments which support a fast transition. As a result, the probabilities will be distributed in the ratio 2:1 in favour of “No” new PM before the 1st of July. A more decisive forecast wouldn’t take into account the involved uncertainties, such as backdoor negotiations within the conservative party, at this point of time.  Sources:

Update: After attempting to read up on the rules and customs of the Conservative leadership contest, I realize that May's successor could be chosen most faster than I had anticipated. I wrongly assumed that the leadership contest would not commence until after May's official resignation date, but it obviously makes sense that it starts close after her announcement. Hence, I looked to  the 2016 contest that followed Cameron's post-referendum resignation.  He announced he was stepping back on June 24th, the 1922 announced the official beginning of the leadership vote on June 27th and by July 11th May wins the leadership vote and takes office on July 13th. Hence, the whole leadership was changed in just 17 days. Should the 2019 contest follow this pattern, a new Prime Minister could indeed take office before July 1st , as May would officially step down.  However, it has been highlighted that while a leadership contest has been ready to commence for a while, with candidates gearing up for campaigning, this one will be a lot longer than the 2016 one. The Conservative party is in extreme crisis and very fractured. While there are favorites to take over for May, there isn't one clear candidate and the process could take a while longer due to the many potential candidates and the need to VERY CAREFULLY contemplate a new leader and the future of the Conservative party. This has led some to report that a new leader could be in place my mid-July.  Evidently, I am still very uncertain about how it will progress from here and I will be keeping close attention to the happenings in the conservative party and attempt to understand the process a little better. However, I do adjust my forecast to increase the likelihood of a new conservative PM before July 1st.

Update: After the resignation of Commons Leader Andrea Leadsom, it seems Theresa May is faced with the erosion of the cabinet that has, up until now, been the basis of her claim to the post as Prime Minister. In the past days, Conservative voices have been ever louder in their criticism of May’s leadership.  Allegedly,  Conservative party members met to discuss a vote to change the party rules that has secured May since her last vote of no confidence. May is set to meet with the 1922 committee tomorrow, Friday May 24th, to discuss the future of the Conservative party leadership. The committee has previously called for her resignation. 
While May has weathered many challenges and internal criticism, it seems the pressure for her resignation is more profound and widespread than previously. An end to May’s run as prime minister could be near!  However, even if May did commit to stepping down in the near future – dates like June 6th, 7th and 10th have been proposed, - it begs the question, if a new Conservative leader would be ready to take over before July 1st? (The idea that May would step down before seems very unlikely considering the American state visit scheduled for June 3rd.) Around May’s last vote of confidence, it was reported that a leadership contest in the Conservative party could take up to 12 weeks, while expected to be quicker in the current state of affairs. However, it seems unlikely that the process could be condensed to just 3 weeks and allow a new Conservative prime minister to take office before July 1st. Some sources have reported that if May agrees to resign in early June, the leadership contest is set to commence in July, thereby not leaving time for a leadership change before the end of June.  While May could step down as head of the conservative party, and not actually leave the position as prime minister, this is a very unlikely scenario, as it is not what the parliament have been calling for! Additionally, May could step down as both leader of the conservative party and prime minister without a new Tory leader waiting to step up. This would require an interim prime minister which is extremely rare and also rather unlikely. (Moreover, would an interim prime minister count as an actual ‘new prime minister’ as the question asks?) .  Hence, while I recognize that these days are crucial for May’s continued time in office, and that the situation could be pointing towards a resignation, it still seems unlikely that a new prime minister will take office before July 1st. https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-48374841

UPDATE 23.05.2019  As I stated in my earlier forecast: 
"It is worth to mention, that the remaining time until the end of this forecast may be enough for staging a successful no confidence vote, however, it seems extremely unlikely that a new PM will be elected by this time regarding the amount of time necessary to proceed and finalize a general election in the UK". A general election won’t take place before the 1 of July anymore (due to the fixed time periods; see earlier forecast). As a result, this forecast will adjust the probability for a new Labour PM to 0%.  The only left alternatives would be that:  a) Theresa May steps down before the 1st of July. This is difficult to estimate as May has been demonstrating her willingness to continue for the last years despite the tough Brexit negotiations and heavy pressure from her own party. However, May proposed to her party that she will step down if they back her new withdrawal agreement. This could be interpreted as fatigue, but also as another try to unite her coalition and lure them into supporting her bill. May’s proposal won’t be published until early June due to the Whitsun recess of the Parliament (which ends at the 4th of June). The “second reading” (first debate on proposal) is vaguely planned for the 7th of June according to government whip Mark Spencer. Some conservative MPs and party members, known as the “backbench 1922 Committee”, held a secret ballot to alter internal party rules in order to initiate another no confidence vote against May if she won’t step down until the 10th of June. The pressure on May is increasing steadily, though the next days will show if this pressure decreases due to the recess or if it sustains. Nevertheless, the probability for this sub-option will be changed to 10% regarding the involved high uncertainties if May is fatigued enough or not; or b) a no-confidence motion will be passed in the Parliament and an alternative Tory government is able to win the confidence vote within a 14 calendar days period (very unlikely due to internal divide of the Conservative party and the Whitsun recess of the Parliament). As a result, this sub-option (b) should be assessed with a 0% probability.  As a result, I will reduce the probability for the option containing a Labour PM to 0% (no new general elections possible) and for a new Tory PM to 10% (May stepping down is very unlikely, but possible). Trying to establish a base rate, I find that in the last roughly 100 years there have been 19 prime ministers. Dividing the two gives a probability of ≈ 19% that a prime minister will change a given year and 81% probability that it will not happen. Since the scope of the question is less that 2 months the estimate ends up at ≈ 4% probability of change before 1 of July 2019, if we were talking about an "average" prime minister.  Looking at the specifics of the UK right now it is reasonable to assume that there is a higher probability because of the Brexit process.  Theresa May has publicly stated that she will not continue as prime minister after Brexit is over, so it is a matter of WHEN not IF. Since Brexit have been postponed until October 2019, and the process still appears to be in a deadlock, I don't think this increases the probability of a new prime minister before July by much more than 2-4% on its own. This number reflects the probability of a Brexit agreement before July. (https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/16/world/europe/uk-theresa-may.html) The leader of Labour, Jeremy Corbyn, recently left negotiations of a Brexit compromise with Theresa May blaming their inability to reach agreement. (https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/17/world/europe/jeremy-corbyn-theresa-may.html). Yet another blow to Theresa May.  On the other hand, there are some things favouring her remaining as prime minister up until the point where the agreement is reached. In a podcast by Danish media Altinget several sources report that a large group in the Conservative Party fears that the replacement will be much worse, such as Boris Johnson. He is likely much more willing to accept the no-deal scenario and just leave.  Dividing the remaining probability between the other three options, the actual outcome of Brexit will have a massive impact upon which party can get the position of prime minister. Since this is an unknown, I have simply given them all equal amounts except for the "other" option.

Update: Theresa May has evidently been facing tremendous internal pressure from the conservative party to resign. Therefore, even though she is protected till the end of the year, she's recently announced that she'll set an election timetable for a new conservative party leader if her deal fails again in June. Her deal is expected to be brought up again beginning in June, but when the actual vote happens isn't known yet. I believe that her deal will fail once again, because it has failed three other times before, there is now no imminent drop out day looming about MPs and conservatives have now been promised that they can get rid of Theresa May if they reject her deal. This means May would have to get the Labour party on board and negotiations with Jeremy Corbyn and Labour leaders have esstentially stalled with Corbyn claiming that talkks "have gone as far as they can". Therefore, it's highly unlikely may will get Labour support.  For these reasons I am I find that Theresa May's deal will almost undoubtedly fail,  thereby triggering conservative party elections. However, if may's deal passes  then she'll continue to be PM at least till July 1st 2019. So whether May leaves by July 1st is really a question on how long leadership elections will take. First and foremost, according to conservative  party rules, the resigning PM will remain PM throughout the elections. Therefore, May's resignation announcement will not actually be the date she leaves office, that date will be when the conservative party chooses their new leader. So to look at dates, May's deal will first come to Parliament on June 3rd, but the likelihood it is voted on immediately is very low. however, it isn't unreasonable to assume that a vote on it will happen by Friday June 7th. So let's assume it fails on June 7th and May then works over the weekend with conservative leaders ans announces her resignation and subsequent timetable for elections on Monday June 10th. From here there are then 3 weeks till Friday June 28th for elections be held and completed for May to cease to be PM by July 1st. Moreover, it'll actually be less than three weeks, because of the nomination process, which normally takes a few days.  For the most part, conservative leaders have allotted a 2 month timetable for election, but rarely is all this time used. In fact leadership election usually take around a month. Thereby, placing May's resignation date eerily close to July 1st. An important aspect of this election procedure is that it is not first past the post, but rather is a succession of run off elections, where the lowest vote getter is eliminated until only two candidates remain and then in this final election is determined by a majority vote. Therefore, a candidate could be getting over 50% of the vote, but will continue to go through elections till they are only facing one other candidate. This system has the has probability of prolonging election over three weeks and into July if there are numerous, stubborn candidates.  Theresa May's assumption to office took just under 3 weeks after Cameron's resignation announcement. However, Theresa May was the clear choice and gained 50% of the vote on the first ballot while running against 4 other opponents and received 60% of the vote on the second ballot while running against 2 other candidates and then four days after her primary opponent dropped out and two days after that Cameroon formally resigned.  Based on this very generous and fast election data, it can be assumed that a round of voting will take 1 week. Therefore, in order for Theresa May to leave office by July 1st there would have to be at maximum 2 rounds of voting, with the possibility of 3 just barely making it in time for a resignation before July 1st.  Therefore, whether Theresa May leaves before July 1st is a question of the number of candidates running for PM, how evident the eventual winner is and how stubborn the other candidates are. At this point in time there do not seem to be any clear choices, as May quickly became when Cameron announced his resignation. Therefore,  I predict that there will be a myriad of candidates and that some of these like Boris Johnson, who has already announced his candidacy, will be very stubborn and won't simply drop out. For these Reason I predict that this election process will require, at minimum 3 rounds of voting. This also isn't unreasonable to conceive, because every conservative leadership election since 1997 till May required 3 rounds or more and the election in 2016 was heading into a 3rd round before May's primary opponent dropped out.  Due to this reasoning, I believe that conservative PM elections will run just barely into July, thereby meaning that May will continue to be PM by July 1st. However, it isn't impossible for her to formally resign before then. There a couple of factors are important to consider that could make this happen. First, May's deal could be voted on in parliament earlier than the June 7th I proposed. May could not drag her feet and already have election plans, thereby announcing elections the day the deal fails or sooner than I predicted. During the election process a clear leader could emerge and a fractured conservative party could come together to swiftly elect a new leader. because of these reasons, I give a 15% probability that May will cease to be PM by July 1st 2019. https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-48290760

Twice, Mrs. May has had to ask the European Union to delay Brexit, and now her Conservatives face fierce competition from a new Brexit party started by Nigel Farage, which argues that Britain should leave the bloc soon, without any agreement if necessary. .
. . . 
. . .  the significance of Thursday’s statement is that Mrs. May has effectively conceded she cannot remain as prime minister if her plan loses for a fourth time, as most analysts believe it will. Going into the meeting inside Parliament on Thursday, Mrs. May had been under pressure to name a specific date for her departure, something she successfully resisted. The agreement struck with her senior lawmakers buys her a few more weeks and the chance to make a final attempt to secure a Brexit vote, and some sort of legacy. Her supporters believe that elections for the European Parliament, scheduled for next week, will be bad news for both the Conservative and opposition Labour parties but hope that could help Mrs. May. They argue that, if Mr. Farage’s Brexit Party performs well, it proves that voters are frustrated at Parliament’s failure to agree on a plan to leave the European Union, which could increase pressure on lawmakers to pass Mrs. May’s Brexit legislation. But most analysts think that Mrs. May will fail again unless she can gain the support of opposition lawmakers. Talks with the Labour Party, meanwhile, are stalling. Within her Conservative Party, activists are planning to hold a meeting on June 15 to discuss a motion of no confidence in Mrs. May. While nonbinding, that would be a huge blow to what remains of her authority. Senior lawmakers have threatened to change internal party rules that protect her from a formal challenge until December. That could mean her having to face a quick contest that she would probably lose. Rather than risk that fate, Mrs. May appears to have finally accepted that a fourth parliamentary failure would make her position untenable.

I agree with what @mariam said yesterday, it looks as Mrs May will have to go, but the manner of her going is not definite. Many Conservatives are said to think that if she goes before the EU Parliamentary Election 23rd May that would be a much needed boost for Conservative candidates. But if she goes before or after the election, as far as this question is concerned, the important issue is if she is pushed by her own MPs to resign immediately or she just agrees to resign asap. 
When Cameron resigned replacing him with May took just under 3 weeks, but this time there is likely to be a lot more candidates, so whittling down to two will presumably take at least a few days more. And in 2016 after the MPs had reduced the candidates to 2, the other candidate (Leadsom) pulled out. If the full election process had been followed I thing it would have taken over a week and more like two weeks to have organised the required vote for all party members. So I would guess that from May announcing she was resigning to a new PM taking over would take it would probably take at least 5 or 6 weeks. There is less than 7 weeks until this question ends. 
It would be possible to do it faster, but presumably they would be more interested in making sure the next PM was the best person, than they would in rushing the process. 
The other possibility would be installing a temporary PM (who would be the new PM as far as this question is concerned) to give more time to choose the permanent replacement, but I don't see what the point would be. A temporary PM would not have authority to do anything apart from maintaining the status quo (and the EU would not want to negotiate Brexit with him/her).
It could be close but if May resigns this week there is a 50% chance there will be a New Conservative PM before 1st July and for every day after that the chances drop by about 1%. We will soon find out, but Mrs May will probably last long enough that a replacement is not in office until after the end of June. 
(There is probably no rush, because if a new PM fancies a different EU WA that has been agreed already with the EU I doubt that the EU would be able to renegotiate before November and to do that A50 woud need to be delayed again. There are not really any good options for anyone who becomes the next PM.)

Theresa May seems unwilling to step down, at least not before the Brexit is done. With the extension of the deadline to October 2019 it seems very unlikely that she will leave the government before the 1 of July 2019. Considering the obstacles which Theresa May had to deal with (no confidence votes, historical defeat in the parliament & etc.) she has proven that she is able to handle the pressure and the lack of support by her own party. For this reason, this forecast will solely focus on the support and opposition Theresa May faces by MPs as potential actors capable of forcing her to step down. Therefore, the forecast at hand will assess the party discipline among parties as the decisive factor which enables the success or failure of potential no confidence votes.  Theresa May won the confidence vote within her party in December 2018, however 117 members of her party voted against her. Another no confidence vote triggered by conservative MPs cannot take place before December 2019. The motion of no confidence in January, proposed by Labour, wasn’t successful neither. Nonetheless, its outcome was a devastating symbolic result for May as she only won by 19 votes with 325 to 306 in her favour due to the support of her party and her coalition partner DUP. Labour might still try to get rid of May through a no confidence vote which would trigger a general election. It is worth to mention, that the remaining time until the end of this forecast may be enough for staging a successful no confidence vote, however, it seems extremely unlikely that a new PM will be elected by this time regarding the amount of time necessary to proceed and finalize a general election in the UK. The following scenario will exemplify how little time is left: a successful no confidence vote tomorrow (10.05.2019; this is very unlikely itself) against the government than would start a 14 calendar days countdown which will expire at the 23rd of May. During this time an alternative government must win a confidence vote. From the 23rd to the 4th of June the Parliament won’t have any sittings due to recess. In the case that none of the alternative governments will succeed (very likely; see below) there has to be a new general election which can take place no earlier than 25 working days after the first time period expired. This means, in the case of a successful no confidence vote at the 10th of May the earliest possible date for a general election, given that no alternative government won the confidence vote until the 23rd of May, will be the 27th of June. The last day for a successful confidence vote in order to get a new PM before the 1st of July, under similar circumstances as before, is the 13th of May. As a result, the parliament has to vote in favour for a no confidence motion in the next two working days in order to appoint a new PM before the 1st of July. As there are no significant indicators which would imply such a move it is relative safe to forecast a 90% likelihood that Theresa May will remain PM until the 1st of July. It is worth to mention that the 1st of July is an arbitrary boundary and, thus, won’t have any effect on the MPs voting decision. The remaining 10% derive from the unlikely possibility that May will step down by herself (see above) or that she will be unable to continue her term as PM. The following analysis should be understood as an estimation to identify which party would be able to appoint the next PM under in such circumstances.  For May the weakened party discipline results in a situation where the slightest disagreement with a conservative MP is synonymic with another lost vote to back her up. It puts the pressure on her to be responsible for maintaining and monitoring the loyalty of each MP of her own party. Therefore, she depends on the support within the parliament more than other PMs before her. Unfortunately for her, the current controversy regarding the Brexit has a negative effect on May’s internal support within the conservative party. The party is split in two major factions: Tories who back May and her Brexit deal and the ones who insist on a hard Brexit and oppose her deal. This latter bloc is one of the main reasons why May’s deal didn’t succeed in the past. However, this bloc still supports May to some extend in order to avoid any possibility for Labour to trigger a new general election. The rise of Nigel Farage’s Brexit party may further consolidate the loyalty of this bloc to May in order to avert new elections which may allow Farage’s party to gain voters from their constituencies. Regardless, May cannot make to many concessions to them as she risks losing the support of Tories and Labours favouring a soft Brexit in the parliament. This internal factional divide in the conservative party makes it very unlikely that one of the blocs will be able to appoint a new PM out of their ranks which is able to gather enough support across the party nor that they will form a coalition to overthrow May together.  Labour on the other hand isn’t in a good spot neither. The Labour party also got split in two halves: one bloc supports Jeremy Corbyn who is in favour of a soft Brexit, while the other bloc opposes their party leader as they prefer to remain in the EU. In the no confidence motion in January Labour voted against May in unity. Nevertheless, this doesn’t mean that Corbyn can rely on the support of all Labour members to get backed up in his attempt to become the next PM. Similar to the conservative party, the newly formed factional divide might prevent a coherent support for one Labour MP to become the next PM in the current heated situation. However, Labour, despite also losing support in recent local elections, benefits from the Brexit as the government, or the Conservative party, is mostly held responsible for its disappointing progression by voters. As a result, it seems more likely that Labour will appoint the next PM in the unlikely event of a successful no confidence vote.  Due to the first-past-the-post-system in the UK, it seems extremely unlikely (less than 1%) that the next PM will be a member of another party. Despite recent gains in the local vote, these other parties are still to small (or characteristically unable to gain a wide support in the UK; e.g.: SNP or DUP). It is also very unlikely that Tories and Labour would choose someone from another party even if there are sporadically new cross-party alliances due to the Brexit.  Note on reference class and base rates: 
The Brexit itself is a novelty in international politics. It is less the nature of the overall process which is new. States separated from their former supranational structure at the end of the Cold War era at a time when more and more former Soviet republics detached themselves from the USSR. However, the Brexit shouldn’t be seen in this context as it represents a process in which a democratic state is detaching itself from a democratic organization (or community) while still trying to maintain close ties in areas such as the economy. Also, this separation doesn’t take place within a national context of revolution or at least strong reformism, but instead happens within an institutionalized framework and in collaboration with the entity the state is separating from. Therefore, it doesn’t make sense to compare base rates of former presidents and prime ministers in ex-soviet states during these times with Theresa May as references. This could happen if: 1) Theresa May resigns as Conservative leader to be replaced by someone else
2) Theresa May is ousted by the Conservatives to be replaced by someone else
3) The government loses a vote of no confidence in parliament and a new government is formed without an election
4) There's a general election and Theresa May loses to another party leader 1) A leadership race typically takes longer than 2 months unless it is a coronation and the PM would be expected to remain in place during that time. A coronation is unlikely next time around as the centrist and right wing factions are vying for supremacy. May has given no indication of imminent intent to resign, and has previously vowed to see the Withdrawal Agreement through parliament before she goes. Negligible chance. 2) This could only happen if the Tories change their party rulebook specifically to oust May as under current rules she enjoys a 12 month grace period since her last attempted ousting in December. It is possible she would continue as PM while waiting for a new leader to be chosen. There is no precedent for anything like this in the post-war era. The last sitting PM to be ousted by their own party was Ramsey MacDonald in the 1930's and he continued as PM regardless. Negligible chance. 3) Only one government has lost a confidence motion in the post war era, a rate of once every 74 years. However, if only minority governments are considered it becomes 1 in 12 years giving a 1.2% chance of occurrence in the next 8 weeks. That one previous occurrence resulted in a general election and the same would be likely to happen again. If it didn't, a non-Tory candidate would need the support of every other party - highly unlikely. I'd guess 0.1% chance of a new Tory PM this way, and a negligible chance for any other party. 4) There were 20 general elections between 1945 and 2017. One every 3.6 years. A 0.5% chance of an election being called in any given week. The last general election took 7 weeks from being called until polling day so realistically one would have to be called within the next week to be completed before 1 July. The polls currently indicate a hung parliament with the Conservatives likely to lose seats - an outcome which would make a Labour minority government more likely than a Conservative one. So 0.5% chance there is an election before 1 July, 0.3% that is also produces a Labour government, 0.1% that it returns May to power, 0.1% that it results in a different Tory PM.

Ok, so there's a lot of interesting possibilities regarding the PM's situation.  1) First is the recent evaluation of the rules governing no confidence challenges. It appears to be possible to change these rules, which would entitle the Party to re-challenge her on June 12th. 2) If the above were to happen, she would have to win the resulting ballot (which she did by 200 to 117 last December) to remain PM. I think it's fairly unclear whether or not those who voted in favour of her last time would do so again. I would lean towards yes, since I think that everyone's vote that day was based on their views on the BREXIT process, which hasn't changed significantly since (aside from the delay). 3) If she were to resign, the most likely outcome would be the winner of the aforementioned leadership vote becoming PM, rather than a general election. However, I think it unlikely that Mrs May would resign before July. She appears to be committed to seeing the BREXIT process through, especially given the prominence of it throughout her premiership. 4) Most unlikely, but another possibility would be ANOTHER no confidence vote from the commons. If some Tory back-benchers were to switch their vote, there could be a general election.
I expect the result of that election would probably be a Labour-LibDem coalition, with both parties now willing to commit to a second referendum, but that's just idle speculation... Overall, I doubt she'll resign. If she's challenged, I doubt she'll be beaten. And I doubt there will be another GE.

According to party rules a there cannot be another vote of no-confidence for 12 months and just recently, the 1922 Committee voted to not change this rule. Therefore, there will not be another vote of no-confidence by July 1st 2019 (https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2019/apr/24/theresa-may-survives-attempt-to-allow-early-no-confidence-vote). Therefore, the only foreseeable way that there will be a new Prime Minister is if Theresa May willingly steps down. She has also shown extraordinary resilience and persistence in the face of tremendous opposition and criticism which makes me believe she will stick it through at least until July 1st, but there remains a small chance she could willingly step down.

Based on the existing evidence. UK PM Theresa May and EU leaders negotiated a delay in March and April 2019 for UK withdrawal from EU, but later the deadline extended to October 2019. The bill would have to pass through both lower House of Commons and upper House of Lords to ratify the deal and leave the EU, and the UK need to take part in the European elections in terms of the EU membership on May 23. If Parliament cannot agree on a deal soon and the UK does not take part in the European elections on 23 May, then a no-deal would happen on 1st June. If the elections take place, then the final line is 31st October. Thus, the UK would have to leave the EU in June without a deal.  There are some hurdles that could make her fall. May 2 2019, the local elections provide the most imminent opportunity for voters, and a bad result could force her to resign.

Update: 
Disclaimer: Being the situation very tangled and complex my analysis will focus on the most important scenarios and not on the less likely and/or irrelevant scenarios that can be traced back to the main ones. Indeed, in this specific case, I think that focusing too much on every tiny detail creates confusion and makes losing the global overview of the event. On the 11th Eu and UK agreed on delaying Brexit to October 31st. According to May’s purpose of ensuring the smoothest possible Brexit, I increase my expectation that May will remain Prime Minister at least until 1st July. Brexit is May's career main goal and the reason of its office.
However, the possible scenarios are the following:
- In my previous forecast I talked about the possibility of an agreement between Corbyn (Labour party) and May. If the agreement is reached before the EU elections (1), MPs vote on it. If it passes (1.1) the UK would negotiate a modified Brexit deal with the EU to make the UK leave as soon as possible (however, there is no evidence the new agreement proposals will be accepted by the EU). If it doesn’t (1.2) go to point (2.2)
- If the agreement is not reached (2) the MPs would vote other options: if they find an alternative agreement (2.1)  go to 1.1, if they don’t find any alternative compromise (2.2) they should decide to take part or not to the EU election. According to the fact that the UK participation was a not avoidable condition for the extension of the art.50, if it won’t be respected, Brexit will have to leave with no deal on 1st June (2.2.1). If UK participates to the elections (2.2.2) a lot of scenario could take place: go back to the approval of May’s deal, re-start negotiations, referendum, cancel the Brexit, general election, no-deal. I think that in all these cases May will conduct the process as Prime Minister (we said a soft Brexit is her aim), except for cases 2.2.1 and maybe 1.1: if UK leaves with no-deal I think May would resign after the Brexit  new prime minister before 1st July. Also, the UK Parliament has rejected the idea of a No-deal, which will be supported by the Labour and by all the MP against a hard Brexit, so I think that scenario 2.2.1. is unlikely to occur.
However, we should also consider that May has expressed her will of avoiding EU elections, so I expect efforts from her to reach an agreement before the end of June. In this scenario she will maybe resign, but I see it very unlikely to occur, because of the previous divergences. To me, the most likely scenarios as the 2.2.2, which would open various possibilities. 
- I think that the no-Brexit MP will take advantages for this extension of article 50 to re-shape the public opinion about the referendum. So far, I’ve said that I see the launch of a new referendum as anti-democratic and politically masochist (look at my old forecast about Brexit), but I don’t exclude it to happen. Indeed, the chaos in the UK Parliament and the continuous delays could pressure citizens to remain in the EU. Also, recent events like the disorder in Belfast can make people re-think about their choice. However, the whole preparation for the hypothetical referendum like the definition of the rules and of the question in the legislation, the campaign takes time (experts at UCL Constitution Unit suggest that the minimum time for all of the required steps is about 22 weeks). I believe May would handle this process, therefore, wouldn’t leave her office before 1st July.
- Labour could table another no confidence motion at any time. If the government loses the vote starts a 14-days countdown: If during that time the current government or any other alternative government cannot win a new vote of confidence, then an early general election would be called. Also, the election cannot occur for at least 25 working days. In this case I think that May wouldn’t participate to the new election, but it’s unlikely to happen before 1st July. Indeed, 14+25=39 days, plus some days to announce the new elections and vote (I would say, minimum one week). This means that the whole process should start at least around half may and anyway wouldn’t leave time to the new prime minister to take office. Moreover, the current government already survived a vote of no confidence on 16 January by 325 votes to 306, which pulls away the possibility of a new vote of confidence.  In conclusion, I don’t think drastic and immediate measures related to no deal would take place, I see more likely other scenarios which implies a longer time to reach a final solution. In this prospective, from my analysis appears that May will remain in charge at least until 1st July. Considering the current situation, it seems that May’s future as PM is very much dependent on whether or not a Brexit deal is agreed upon before UK’s scheduled EP elections on May 23rd.  As with any forecast related to Brexit, it is a difficult prediction to make and there are few prerequisites that are worth establishing: 
-	Theresa May has previously declared that she will resign as soon as her Brexit deal has been delivered. It is assumed this apply to any Brexit deal.
-	The Fix- parliaments act regulates when elections will occur: Elections are to be held every 5th year, unless parliament vote for no confidence in government or a vote of 2/3 of house of commons want a general election. 
-	In the wake of a no confidence vote, any MP has the right to attempt to assemble a majority in parliament and form a new government within 2 weeks. 
-	After an election is called, it is to be held within 25 working days. 
-	In accordance with the Conservative Party rules, May cannot be forced from her position by her own party 
till December 2019, as she has recently survived the no confidence vote.   The UK has been granted an extension on article 50 till October 31st 2019. This extension is dependent upon the UK holding EP elections on May 23rd, unless they manage to agree on a Brexit deal before this date. In case the UK fails to secure a Brexit deal and do not hold the EP elections, they are forced to leave the EU on June 1st without a deal.  Theresa May and other MPs have on several occasions expressed their desire to avoid British participation in the EP election. Consequently, they will be working very hard to secure a Brexit deal before this date. In case they do secure a deal before May 23rd, it is expected that May will resign immediately following this. May’s resignation will, in turn, initiate a leadership contest within the Conservative party to elect a new party leader and PM. In this scenario, a new conservative PM could take office before July 1st.  However, as the parliament has repeatedly failed to secure a deal, it is unlikely that they will manage to do so before May 23rd. While some conservative MPs might be pushed to support May’s deal in a last bid to avoid the EP election, most pro-EUs are even less likely to support a deal and instead utilize the EP elections as a means to showcase the continued support for Britain in the EU. As May, and a majority of parliament, have expressed their commitment to avoid a hard Brexit, May will most likely hold the EP elections to avoid just that. If the EP elections are held, May will most likely not leave her position as PM and she will instead remain in office to continue her work to secure a deal before October 31st.  Should the EP elections be held, parliament could initiate yet another ‘vote of no confidence’ to attempt to overturn the Conservative government. In accordance with the ‘fix parliament act’, this would allow for any MP to seek to establish a majority and form a new government within 2 weeks. However, due to the current chaotic nature of British politics, it is very unlikely that anyone would be able to achieve this. This would result in a general election 25 workings days later. A time horizon of 14 days + 25 days would not leave enough time for a new PM to take office before July 1st. Moreover, since WWII, only one government has been brought down by vote of ‘no confidence in government’. Theresa May and her government survived a no confidence vote in January 2019.  It is very unlikely that a Brexit deal will be reached closely after the EP elections. The elections will most likely instead result in calls for another referendum, re-negotiations etc.  In conclusion, whether a new prime minister takes office before July 1st seems to be mostly dependent upon whether a deal is secured before the EP elections or not. In case the parliament manages to secure a deal within the foreseeable future, Theresa May will most likely step down and another Conservative will take over. However, as of now, it seems unlikely that a deal will be reached. This will result in EP elections and after those, May will likely only leave office if she loses a ‘no confidence vote’. But in the case of a no confidence vote, a new PM will not be in office before July 1st. It seems very unlikely that either someone from either Labour or another party will become PM before July 1st.  Sources:

85% - I consider that it is very likely that May will remain Prime Minister minimum until 1 July 2019. There was much of doubt if May remains in the office back to the period of December - January when May was facing a vote of confidence in her leadership of the Conservative Party as well as a vote of no confidence in her government. However, many things have changed. Looking from today's perspective, May time in the office mostly depends on the future of Brexit deal. As she said herself, she will leave the Prime Minister's post as soon as the agreement will be achieved between the UK and EU. On 11th April, EU and UK agreed to delay Brexit to October 31st. Therefore, it is very likely that she remains Prime Minister until then.  15% (14+1) - As one of the EU conditions to delay the Brexit was an obligation for the UK to hold the EU Parliament Election. As now it is only a matter of time when the UK leaves the EU, many Brexiteers are angry about participating in elections at all, seeing it as only a waste of time and money. In addition, May herself made a statement that the UK can still leave before 22 May, if Parliament backs the withdrawal agreement she reached with the EU. In this case, the UK could also avoid EU elections. if Parliament agrees with May's Brexit deal - May has already decided to leave the office and, therefore, a new Prime Minister will have to be elected. As Tories are quite confident at leading the polls, it is a high probability that the Prime Minister would also be a conservative. Due to the unavoidable uncertainty, I gave 1 % of chance to Labour candidate even though I find it hard to imagine that someone from the Labour Party would lead the process of UK exiting the EU.
However, looking at the previous UK parliament's votes when all possible Brexit solutions were rejected, it is considered very unlikely that Parliament somehow would switch their support towards May's deal in less than two months. Therefore, the chances of the UK and EU to reach an agreement and May to be replaced before July, are quite small. Sources:

Update:  On April 10th 2019, the EU accepted a “flexible” delay of the Brexit, until October 31st 2019. The following scenarios are left to consideration:  May and Corbyn come to an agreement before the European elections (May 23-26th) and the Parliament approves the agreement: 
A.   The UK leaves the EU with an agreement before October 31st 2019  (2) May and Corbyn come to an agreement before the European elections (May 23-26th) but the Parliament disapproves the agreement and the UK government does not organize the EU elections: 
   “No deal” and the UK leaves the EU on 1st June 2019.  (3) May and Corbyn come to an agreement before the European elections (May 23-26th) but the Parliament disapproves the agreement and the UK government organizes the EU elections 
Brexit is postponed once again
The UK remains in the EU
The UK Parliament is again consulted on the agreement 
	a. the UK Parliament disapproves: unknown outcome
	b. the UK Parliament approves: The UK leaves the EU with an agreement before October 31st    (4) May and Corbyn fail to come to an agreement before the EU elections, the UK government does not organize the EU elections
A. “No deal” and the UK leaves the EU on 1st June 2019.  (5) May and Corbyn fail to come to an agreement before the EU elections, the UK government organizes the EU elections: 
Brexit is postponed once again 
The UK remains in the EU 
The UK Parliament approves the agreement: the UK leaves the EU with an agreement before October 31st 2019 
The UK Parliament disapproves the agreement: unknown outcome Forecast: 
The UK Parliament rejected the idea of leaving the EU without a deal. Discontented with Brexit, the opposition will not let the worse case scenario unfold, adding to the determination of the UK Parliament not to turn into an accidental “no-deal” Brexit. Hence, I see scenarios (2) and (4) as less likely to happen. In that sense, I do not expect May to be facing a "no-deal" and thereby, forced to leave office in such circumstances (in June 2019). I expect May to remain Prime Minister passed July 1st 2019 because I expect future events to tip towards May’s deal. But, I think the UK Parliament will take advantage of the fact that Brexit has been postponed to October 31st. In that sense, I see scenarios (3) C.b & (5) C as to be most likely, with (3) C. a. & (5) D remaining in the panel of fair possibilities. Hence, I find more probability in the UK Parliament and May to converge towards a “positive” outcome, but requiring May to cling onto her patience. In any case, I believe that May will not give up until Europe has run out of opportunities.  Nevertheless, Brexit remains a topic of high uncertainty. Therefore I assign a probability of 20% for a new Prime Minister to take on the UK before the 1st July 2019. With a Conservative majority in Parliament, the successor would be found in this party. If it was Cameron in Mays position now then yes he would definitely be replaced. However, May, Corbyn and the Queen seem to have a deep sense of duty and the numbers stacked against them actually make them more solid in their sense of duty and resolve. However, ultimately May will put her party and the national interest above all else and will resign if she feels it is the least worst option. It is likely that Theresa Mays foes actually want her to be scapegoated with as much baggage as possible and will want her to continue for the time being so that they can strategise and kick her out once as much damage and blame can be laid at her doorstep and hard decisions can't be inherited any more. However, a very possible very poor showing in the European elections could make the the negative noise around her so great that it will be seen by Theresa May as the reason to step down and for her foes to go in for the kill (against some of their own desires to wait) and she could step down swiftly for the sake of Brexit and her party. However, she is likely to resist this in the belief that a transition to a new leader without any form of a deal would be too much of a self inflicted wound at such a vulnerable and critical moment. She will weigh what will be the greatest cause of weakness, the noise around her or a transition to a new leader and ultimately her decision will be based on this. It could be quite likely that a strong Labour showing (possibly double the vote of the Conservatives based on initial polling) will make her position untenable and she will leave. She would be blamed for this good showing by her actions in legitimising Labour and their Brexit ideas by reaching out to them for a deal. It is unlikely that any general election poll will be called prior or after the European elections given the weak state of the parties and a transition to a new leader is the most likely outcome and therefore it is unlikely that Corbyn can get in. If a general election were held today Corbyn and Labour would win because they have now been cast in a positive light given Theresa Mays reliance on going to them and their ideas to break the impasse.

May cannot be forced to step down as party leader until the end of the year, and I doubt she would hold a general election for fear of losing more seats and potentially allowing Labour a majority. She has shown that she is incredibly inflexible and obdurate, so I do not think she will step down until either she is forced to, or some resolution has been reached on Brexit so that she can consider her job done.  I think it is unlikely that either of these will happen sufficiently soon for her to be replaced by 1 July (partly because I think it would make more sense for either an election or a leadership contest to take place during the summer recess, which begins on 24 July).  Therefore, I think by far the most likely outcome is that she will be in power on 1 July (though if there is either an election or a leadership contest I think she would, in practice, more or less have to stand down).  If she is replaced, it is far more likely to be because she stood down as party leader than because she triggered an election, and in that case there would automatically be a Conservative replacement.  And even if an election is called, it is not at all clear that Labour would claim a majority, so for those two reasons the probability of a Conservative replacement must be significantly higher than the probability of a Labour replacement.  I think the prospect of a non Labour/Conservative replacement is practically zero, but have said 1% as I can't really say that there is no possibility whatsoever of that happening.

Some days before the supposed final date for Brexit (29th March), because of the chaotic situation of the Parliament, May has stated that if the MP would have approved her withdrawal agreement with the EU she would have resigned. This is the clear demonstration that her main goal since her nomination has been getting out of EU in the more convenient and less disorganised way. So, I don’t think she will resign till she would have reach the Brexit. Five days ago May has proposed an extension of the art. 50 till the 30th of June, and the EU needs to choose if approving it or not (today/tomorrow). An approval will mean no pressure about taking a decision before 12th April or 22nd of May, but also confirm the participation of the UK to the European elections.
Moreover “Prime Minister Theresa May has won a vote of confidence in her leadership of the Conservative Party in December 2018 after securing 63% of the total vote: she is now immune from a leadership challenge for a year”. In the next month she will remain in charge trying to unblock the situation (60% probability), proposing for the fourth time the agreement to the UK parliament or restart the negotiations with UE. However, the deadlock in the Parliament can open other possibilities. The MP have demonstrated to be unable to reach an agreement on no-one of the 8 possible solutions proposed in the end of March, showing the division inter and intra parties. Because May can’t gather all the votes of her party (divided in who wants an hard and who a soft brexit) other scenarios are likely to occur. In the last days, because of the deep disagreement in her party, May has started negotiations with Jeremy Corbin, the leader of the Labour Party (at the opposition) in order to obtain a softer Brexit. In front of such a deadlock another possibility would be going for snap elections. However, the chaotic situation is dropping the approval rating for May but also for the entire conservative party, seen more and more as unable to manage the Brexit and to satisfy the citizens expectation and in this case Labour could maybe win. I think that this new election scenario is very unlikely to occor because Conservative parties are aware of the possibility of losing at this turn and would do their best to avoid them. That’s why I asset the possibility of a Labour prime minister at 10% and of another party one at 0% Indeed, I believe that no new forces could arise so quickly and gain enough population support. Plus, the Brexit issue is fragmented enough, such as the two main parties: I think the Britain people doesn’t want to add a new front in the debate.
Instead, I see more likely the possibility of a new referendum, so much requested by the Labourists, even if May doesn’t like this option because, again, her aim is respecting the Britain will and deliver on the 2016 referendum outcome.

May’s leadership has been orientated on Brexit. It appears her sole objective is to deliver on the referendum vote of 2016. This was made clear last week when she offered to resign in exchange for an approval of her withdrawal agreement. It appears then, that once she has produced a deliverable on Brexit, May will be inclined to resign — having fulfilled her objective as Prime Minister. Thus, whether May will still be Prime Minister on July 1 will likely depend on whether a Brexit agreement is finally made in the coming months. We know that having won a vote of no confidence in December, she is immune to another until the end of this year. Thus the scenarios in which May ceases to be PM in July are two fold: 1) she resigns, and 2) a snap election is called and the opposition wins.  1. Resignation
If a Brexit deal is delivered, as mentioned, this seems probable. It is also seems possible if, unable to deliver a deal, she accepts defeat. We have witnessed extraordinary actions by MPs crossing the floor and voting against their own party/ government — illustrating the party’s fragility and May’s weakening authority. In the last few days, she has also been been negotiating strategy with opposition leader, Jeremy Corbyn, which may fuel more anger and chaos within her own party. A failure to deliver a solution may result in her disenfranchisement, pushing May to step aside for another in her party to instigate new efforts at producing something tangible. May has endured many turbulences however, and seems determined to deliver. If a deal is not made, and a longer extension is granted, this may compel her to hold onto leadership to see a solution through to the end. At this stage though, she has voiced intention to apply for a short extension — seemingly optimistic that a solution can be agreed upon in the short-term. 2. Snap election
An early election may be a means for overcoming the deadlock the government faces. It appears that satisfying the majority of members is a near impossible task — based on May’s failure to do so despite the high stakes. This seems an unlikely move, however. Given that the drama surrounding Brexit has divided the nation, the government risks losing leadership at this point in time. It seems more likely they will call a referendum to make progress on Brexit solutions before they call a general election, as this puts the government and May in a real (and probably) position to be defeated. Thus, the forecast that the Prime Minister of the UK will be a member of the Labour Party on July 1, is low (5%). The chance a member from a party other than labour or the conservatives is considered so improbable it has been exclude from consideration — no other party wields enough political or voting power to take leadership, even if a snap election were to take place.  In sum:
This determines the least likely leadership scenarios on July 1 to be PM from Labour (5%) or a member from a party other than the Conservatives or Labour (0%). It will largely come down to May’s decision to step aside for the good of her party in the face of a longer extension, or her resignation in response to successfully delivering on the goal of her term (Brexit). Given her endurance thus far, it seems most likely that another member will assume leadership only in the instance that a deal is delivered and she steps down; only a major upheaval within the party would have her resign without delivering a deal. This may be ignited with her negotiations with the opposition, however. Ultimately, this forecast thus comes down to whether or not a tangible plan on Brexit is solidified in the coming months. With pressure mounting from both within the EU and UK, and considering May’s optimism, it is foreseeable that something will be produced in the short term. However, it must be considered that May, with or without a solution, could want to see out her term (or at try to unify her party before another vote of no confidence can possible remove her).  It is difficult to determine who will hold leadership position by July, but May seems slightly more likely than another member of her party at this stage as a decision of Brexit will may take some time. Even if, as May hopes, a short extension is enough to find an agreement, this will take some months — a swift resignation thereafter will cut close to July. Thus, at this stage, a 55% prediction that May will remain in office until at least July 1 is given, while 40% is given to the prospect of another member from her own party.  This forecast is expected to change rapidly as new developments unfold.

This is certainly a hairy one to dive into, but let's see what we can do. I'll be going about this in reverse order from normal, first establishing odds of each party/party category taking the post, then the odds of their being an opening in the first place.
** Disclaimer: I'm coming into this knowing very little about UK politics, so all of the grains of salt should be taken with whatever is below. First and foreleast, the probability of a party other than the two primaries taking the post is effectively impossible. More intriguing is the fight between labour & conservative parties, and it's worth noting that the only scenario, or at least the only one I'm aware of, in which rule would change hands would be in the event of a snap general election changing the simple-majority to the labour party, thus the odds of any non-conservative being appointed in the event of May's resignation is effectively impossible. On the note of that resignation scenario though, I would say at this points it's far more likely a scenario than normal for this (i.e. May throwing around her resignation as a sweetener to her Brexit deal like a BOGO deal at TJ Max...). Thus borrowing a little from @Scott_R's analysis I have the following...
 - Baseline Rate of PM Resignition (Since 1940) = 18.8%
 - Assuming a volatility of 300%, current likelihood = 72.9% (did a sketchy bit of calculating here but it puts it near betting odds, so we'll see (note 1 below))
 - Likelihood of death, 1.3% scaled for time remaining until deadline = about 0.4%
 - Total = 73.3% And for the probability of a snap general election, given the split house this would require at least 98 of 317 seats held by the majority to vote for it. I'm not going to say this is impossible but to be honest this is effectively like voting for the iceberg while riding the Titanic... Which the UK honestly seems to be doing a lot of lately, so screw it let's say 10%. Given this scenario I figure betting odds aren't a bad way to go, the current breakdown is as follows...
 - Labour: 45%
 - Conservative: 39%
 - Other: 16% (Bit surprising but let's go with it) Plugging in the above mess then spits out the following...
Yes, Conservative: 76.5%
Yes, Labour: 5.2%
Yes, Other: 1.6%
No: 16.7% Note 1: Calculation used - (1 - ( (1 - BaseRate) * (1/Volatility) ) ) = (1 - ((1 - 0.188) * (1 / 3.0)) ) = 0.729 (72.9%)
Note 2: If May survives the April 12th deadline for the Brexit deal then I plan to bring this volatility number down
Note 3: Calculations page: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/12NqmZW4ZWLFKRlkcgUIhqPnhhVlS2btR_Q4WRlbAdSM/edit?usp=sharing
Adding the possibility of general election before July 1st.

As base-rate for the forecast at hand serves the history of Prime Minister resignations in the UK since 1945. In total, 8 of the 13 Prime Ministers (62%) that governed the UK after 1945 had to leave office before the regular end of their respective terms. Only one resignation was the product of a no-confidence vote and a party switch in the government after a corresponding general election. In the other 7 cases the prime ministers that took over office from the resigning precursors were members of the same party. While three of the PM resignations were connected to individual issues, such as health or scandals, the vast majority, namely 5 were related to major political decisions, 1 domestic and 4 international. Particular, interesting is that the international-related resignations were related to issues concerning either the Middle-East or Europe. Turning to the Europe-related cases it is furthermore very interesting that both resignations Thatcher and Cameron were members of the conservative party. While in the case of Thatcher arguably other issues lead to her defeat, too, one great difficulty during her time in office was the issue of Europe. Her long-serving Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe resigned in November 1990 in protest at her attitude to Europe. His resignation speech brought about events which were to lead to her exit from 10 Downing Street later that month. Michael Heseltine challenged her for the leadership, and while he failed to win, he gained 152 votes – enough to make it evident that a crucial minority favoured a change. Thatcher was eventually persuaded not to go forward to the second ballot, which was won by her Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major. John Major himself struggled with his party over Europe afterwards, too. He secured a number of opt-outs from the Maastricht Treaty regarding social policy and membership of the single currency – but this was not enough for a number of his colleagues. Throughout the rest of his time as Prime Minister, he suffered from continued attacks from his own party and Cabinet on Europe, which played a role in destabilising the government - however, he remained in office. Finally, in 2016 PM Cameron resigned after the Brexit referendum, when he campaigned to stay within the EU, but the majority of the British voted to leave. This very referendum is also crucial for the destiny of current conservative PM May and thus for the question at hand.  In sum, 62% of PM after World War II had to leave office early. Only once a no-confidence vote was successful with new general elections and ultimately a prime minister from a different party. Turning to the Tories it must be considered that all 3 conservative precursors of May were struggling over Europe - with only Major who could end his term - though the struggle over Europe was crucial in the lost general elections. Based upon that and further increased through the dramatic tensions in the UK related to Brexit, as well as May’s announcement to be will to step back under certain conditions, the forecast at hand estimates a 65% likelihood of Theresa May to be replaced by a conservative party member. A 10% likelihood is estimated for Labor PM to replace her, due to the fact that one of the 10 (non-individual-related) resignations was a product of a non-confidence vote. Correspondingly, the forecast at hand estimates the likelihood of May staying Prime Minister after July 1, as of 20% and due to the high degree of uncertainty related to Brexit a 5% probability of a replacement that is neither member of Labour, nor the Conservatives.  *The information for the Base-rates were gathered from the official Prime Minister profiles as of presented by the British Government: https://www.gov.uk/government/history/past-prime-ministers

After much turmoil in the last weeks, Theresa May has vowed to resign as prime minister of the UK if the parliament votes in favor of the deal she has negotiated with the EU stating that she knows "there is a desire for a new approach – and new leadership – in the second phase of the Brexit negotiations" and "won’t stand in the way of that". (https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2019/mar/27/theresa-may-to-resign-before-next-phase-of-brexit). She has not announced a specific date for her withdrawal, however provided that she can finally secure a majority for her deal (which seems unlikely) and she stays true to her word, this has to happen until May 22, the date the EU has set as a new deadline for the UK leaving the EU.  Today on May 29, parliament is set to vote for a third time on May's deal. Despite her attempt to secure the support of hardline-Brexiteers by tying the vote with a promise to step down, everything points to another defeat. While some Brexiteers, most notably Boris Johnson have said, they are prepared to vote in favor, May still lacks support of most of the opposition as well as 10 MP's of the Northern Irish DUP, who remain adamant in their opposition to the deal and about 20 conservative party members opposed to leaving the EU in the first place. If the deal miraculously gets through, the UK has time until May 22 to leave the EU. May will likely step down from office until or shortly after that date. If not, the UK must either leave or convince the EU to grant a further extension until April 12. May has not indicated whether she would remain in office in this case but both scenarios render that possibility unlikely: If the UK fails to come up with a new plan and is forced to leave without a deal, May would take all the blame and almost certainly be forced to step down. If another extension is granted in between now and April 12, she could carry on longer but would incur the ire of the Brexiteers who would feel betrayed and troubled by the chance of a second referendum.  Anticipating a defeat, May might already be prepared to push for a fourth vote in the time remaining until April 12. (https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/commentary/theresa-may-offers-stand-down-as-british-prime-minister-11388870). Chances are that some MP's from both the conservative party and the opposition, horrified by the prospect of a no deal would finally throw their support behind her. Regardless of the outcome of the third (and potentially fourth) vote, it is likely that May's days in Downing Street No. 10 are numbered. Cabinet members have already discussed installing a caretaker (https://www.ft.com/content/878b966e-4dbe-11e9-b401-8d9ef1626294). This remains a possibility, especially in the event of a crushing defeat. However, it also presupposes that she resigns on her own terms, as Tory party rules dictate that another leadership challenge cannot be brought against her until December (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-03-22/u-k-cabinet-ministers-are-wargaming-the-fall-of-theresa-may). Thus, even amidst seemingly growing pressure, from the in- and outside, there is a slight chance that May, will hold on to power for a while, especially if she is pushing for another vote or hoping to work out a another extension with the EU (though that would likely mean that the UK would have to participate in the European Elections, a prospect dreaded by many conservatives). It has become more and more evident, that within the conservative party, there is already a fight going on for May's succession with Boris Johnson, Michael Gove, Jeremy Hunt, Sajid Javid, and Dominic Raab being among the most prominent contenders. If May resigns, it is likely that a conservative MP will take over. First, because the hurdles of holding general elections are quite high, effectively requiring a (government proposed) motion passed by a two thirds majority or a successful vote of no confidence against the government (https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-6864151/What-happens-Theresa-wins-vote-really-election-loses.html). Second, since opinion polls have been static for a long time, with slight losses for both Labour and the Conservatives (who are still ahead). (https://www.theweek.co.uk/94729/who-will-be-the-next-prime-minister-betting-odds-and-polls). At the same time, the deadlock between the Tory-led government and the parliament is likely to take its toll on the conservative party and none of the aforementioned candidates can be sure to gather support from every faction in the internally divided party. Add to this the possible scenarios of a hard Brexit, a second referendum or a participation in the European elections, all of which are dreaded by party members and part of the population alike. If things go awry, this might well play into the cards of Labour.  In summary: 80% Someone from the Conservative Party: Very likely given the fact that candidates are already positioning themselves, the obstacles for holding general elections and the polls showing the Tories ahead of every other party.  15% Someone from the Labour Party: Unlikely since Labour just like the conservatives is internally divided and their leader Jeremy Corbyn lacks the support of a large part of the population (https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/dec/15/jeremy-corbyn-slides-in-approval-ratings-in-spite-of-tory-schisms). However, much depends on how the Brexit plays out and who is assigned the blame. 0% Someone from neither Labour or the Conservatives: No chance. None of the other parties is strong enough to challenge the conservatives. There is no sign of a candidate from another party enjoying bipartisan support and likewise no political movement like Emmanuel Macron's La République En Marche, that isn't associated with one of the parties. 5% May will remain in power: Unlikely but not completely impossible if she loses the vote (and possible consecutive votes) on her withdrawal deal but manages to secure a further extension of the deadline from the EU.
