The resignation pledge is conditioned on getting MV3 through the commons. My rough guess is this remains unlikely (P~.25) - even though this pledge may get the brexiteer wing of the Tory party on side, this may not be complete, the remain wing of the tories may still go against, most other parties are strongly opposed, and DUP are far from guaranteed to abstain/vote for. (Not to mention the speaker is standing firm on the requirements for the Govt to hold a vote in the first place) 2. Naturally, this doesn't meant the opposite is true - if MV3 doesn't pass, May still may end up resigning. Offering to resign underlines the weakness of the PM. Yet her position is more secure that it may seem: another no confidence vote cannot be held before question deadline, so there's no 'hard' way for the Tory party to oust her. There is an outside chance of a snap GE, but I doubt the conservatives are going to be eager to go into this given their plurality and likely facing public blame for Brexit so-far. So on the other side of the decision tree I give ~20% of turbulence taking its toll before then. I expect these forecasts will change a lot in the coming days, so perhaps the (recent) crowd offering higher estimates will be vindicated.

I am reducing my forecast from 100% as May has made leaving conditional on her deal getting through (not at all certain it will go through) and it is said she wants to attend G20 meeting on 28th & 29th June. Of course if the indicative votes do not work she will claim she was right all the time.

Before July 1, 2019, a new prime minister could arrive in two ways, either a successful no-confidence vote or a resignation from current Prime Minister Theresa May. Current Brexit Context: The EU has granted an extension until April 12 for Theresa May to get the agreement accepted. However, the agreement seems so uncertain to be successful that Theresa May does not consider it worthwhile to represent it a third time.
In addition, an outright revocation of the Brexit is called for by an online petition on the Parliament website signed by more than 5.5 million people in five days, a historic record. Position of May:
- Prime Minister Theresa May has won a vote of confidence in her leadership of the Conservative party by 200 to 117. After securing 63% of the total vote, she is now immune to a leadership challenge for a year (https: // www. bbc.com/news/uk-politics-46547246).
This means that the internal trust (conservatives) is acquired for 1 year, and therefore the arrival of a new prime minister by this way is not possible for July 1, 2019. Nevertheless, she lost 1/3 of its supports.
-On January 16, 2019, Theresa May won a no-confidence vote by 325 to 306. The PM won the vote by a margin of 19, including 10 votes from the DUP. If the party voted against her, she would have lost by one (https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-46899466). The Tory MPs, however, unanimously supported her in the vote (the 314 voted for it). External trust is therefore extremely weak, and hard brexiters of the DUP can change everything. If the Brexit is not done in their own way (Hard Brexit) or is not done at all, they will not give their support (as they did by rejecting the Brexit agreements of May).
-Theresay May serves as PM for one purpose: deliver the Brexit and leave the European Union. If Brexit becomes impossible, she will resign for sure.
-She said she will step down as leader before the next elections in 2022. Base rate of no-confidence votes in the XX and XXI centuries(Source: House of Commons Library)
- Conservative governments have seen off 20 confidence votes
- Labor has won 12 - and only one was lost (in 1979, Callaghan was defeated)
The Base rate tends to show that the vote of no confidence may not be the most likely way to have a new prime minister. Possibility of next Prime Minister (there is no possibility for an another party):
Corbyn (Labor)
Lidington (Tory)
Gove (Tory) Forecast:
Theresa May will not leave because of an internal confidence vote. A vote of no-confidence (external) could push her out, but according to the base rates, it seems less likely, and especially knowing that she has won one (even if it was very short). Resignation would be the most likely way. Anyway, the pressure tightening on her, and no matter what happens, May will be strongly criticized by two camps out of three (Pro-EU, Hard Brexiters, Soft Brexiters).
-Indeed, April 12 is a crucial date, because if Theresa May's Brexit agreement is not accepted by then, there will be the vote to hold European elections (in order to have an another extension for May), or the no-deal.
-In case of no-deal, Labor and the Soft-Brexiters will be extremely irate, as well as the population and the economic circles, and the pressure will be so strong that the uncertainty will reign in the country, which could push May to give up .
-In case of a decision to make European elections, the Soft and Hard Brexiters will feel aggrieved, and May could end up either vulnerable to a vote of no-confidence, or she could resign, seeing the possibility of Brexit (her only mission) gone, especially if the demand for a second referendum is very strong in the new deadline until May.
-If the agreement is accepted, the Labor but especially important the DUP (and some Tory Hard Brexiters) will not be satisfied, and Theresa May will be extremely vulnerable to a vote of no-confidence.
May's room for maneuver is extremely weak, and she is forced in any case to frustrate two camps to have only the support of one, which leads to a precarious situation for her. Similarly, May met on March 25 with some Brexiters, who would have tried to negotiate their support for the deal in exchange for an early resignation of the Prime Minister.
The next few weeks seem to show a likely coup de grace in one way or another for a PM in crisis of authority. However, nothing is done, and we should not be so pessimistic for her, she has been very combative and resilient since the Brexit referendum (indeed, the threats of putsch of her ministers against her were disarmed very quickly), and she could always succeed a tour de force to stay in power by July 2019 and put forward the Brexit, its ultimate (and only) political goal.
The shift is becoming more likely given the tenuous outcome of the pending Brexit deal (or lack thereof)

The options now available to the UK following the EU meeting are:
1. May's WA gets through parliament next week.
1.1 A period until 22nd May will allow parliament to complete the legislation needed. 
I would expect Mrs May to be remain as PM to complete this first stage of Brexit. The second stage of Brexit, the New Trading relationship will in theory start by 23 rd May, but in practice due to the EU Parliament elections and electing a new EU Commission they will not really start until the autumn.  2. May's WA does not get through parliament.
2.1 The UK then has until 12th April to decide if it wants to take part in the EU parliamentary elections.
2.1.1 If the UK takes part in the UK parliamentary elections it can extend A50 in order to discuss options with the EU other than May's WA. These options could include a referendum, and/or a general election, and/or a different WA/Political Statement.
2.1.2 If the UK does not agree to taking part in the EU parliamentary elections it will leave the EU with no deal on 
12th April. So how does that affect Mrs May? If the UK leaves the EU on 12th April it seems very likely she will resign. She would be able to claim that she had delivered Brexit, but I doubt if many people would thank her. So I think she would resign asap after 12th April before people start to notice too much damage.  If the UK takes part in EU parliamentary elections Mrs May will resign as she has said she rejects the ideas of fighting a general election, is against a referendum, and is against any alternative Brexit outcome to her WA. If she did not offer to resign she would be forced out as it has become very obvious she is not suited to getting a Brexit deal. If May's WA is passed by parliament she will resign sometime after completing the legislation on 22nd May and the start of negotiating the New Trade Arrangements. She could claim Brexit victory as long as she does not start the NTA negotiations which are likely to be long and difficult and its generally considered she would not be good at it. An earlier resignation would be better as it would give a new PM more opportunity to plan what to do.     If May resigns or is forced out it (almost) certain that she would be replaced by another Conservative, as they have the most seats in parliament.  So the only one of these options that are likely to see Mrs May remain as PM after 22nd May is if her WA gets through parliament, and even then there will be pressure on her to resign asap, but she might hold on until July. If you trust Mr Macron as a Forecaster Mrs May has only a 5% chance of the UK parliament voter her WA through. I think the chances are a little better, maybe 20%? And if she does get her WA through there is maybe a 30% chance of her holding on until July. So that gives Mrs May a 6% chance of remain PM until 1st July.

At this point - after utter failure - I suspect May must be looking for a way out. She keeps digging her hole deeper. You don’t escape with further digging (and she’s not clever enough to think of digging a ramp up and out).  Her own MP’s will ramp up rebellion because voters have had enough.

Mrs May's position has deteriorated considerably in the last 24 hours.  Her attempt to directly address the "people" and blame parliament for the Brexit mess went down very badly with MPs, and it is the votes of the MPs, not the "people" that she needs to get her WA through parliament. MPs were angry that May said that MPs had not said what they wanted, just what they did not want, when it has been Mrs May who has been blocking them from having free votes on any options (free votes being ones where MPs are allowed to vote according to what they think as opposed to whipped votes where they have to vote according to party directions.) The EU has upped the anti by taking Mrs May at her word (that she would not agree to a long extension) and offering only a shorter extension that she asked for (to May 22nd not June 30th) and said no further extension to that could happen. 
I might be completely deluded, but this looks like negotiating tactics by both Mrs May and the EU. Both want to see who blinks first; the EU, Mrs May or MPs. 
Polling shows that the UK public blame the UK government for the mess and Mrs May specifically.
An online petition from UK voters to parliament calling for A50 to be revoked has been crashing all day because of an unprecedented volume of traffic.   
Parliament has now rejected the WA twice and instructed Mrs May to avoid a No Deal. It is possible but very unlikely that parliament will cave in and now vote for what MPs have already judged to be bad deal. And some of those who voted against the WA want no deal, so are not going to change their votes to avoid no deal.
The EU is very unlikely to back down.
Parliament might take control of events from Mrs May in the next few days. It is believed that the EU would agree to a long extension of A50 if for good reason, but if Mrs May refuses to request it then MPs could (without needing government permission or the PMs agreement) revoke A50 (a court case established in was in parliaments power).
The bottom line is that its difficult to see how May can survive unless she get her WA voted through.

It goes without saying that the public and Conservative MPs are not happy with Mrs May. In my opinion May has given up on concluding Brexit. It seem obvious that she has no idea how once the Withdrawal Agreement gets through parliament she could get the Future Relationship agreed with the EU and Parliament. The problem she has created for herself is that the Political Statement that is attached to the WA, which was supposed to be the Framework for the Future Relationship is no such thing. It is just as an aspirational wish list of contradictory statement that could never be delivered as a Free Trade Deal with the EU. It would be far harder to get any agreement than the WA has been. I think even Mrs May must realise that, and if she does not most Conservative MPs must realise its is beyond her. 
So I think that once either May's WA is through parliament or has been finally killed off and replaced by another WA and Political Statement Mrs May will resign as PM. This could happen by the end of this month. I would expect that if A50 has to be extended for longer than a few weeks, the EU will want the UK to provide a plan of what it intends to do. I don't expect the EU will give anything but a "short extension" to clear up loose ends if May's WA get through parliament by 29th March. If this happens I would expect Mrs May to resign by June.
If Mrs May cannot get her WA through parliament the EU will not give a "short extension" to A50, but would need to give a "long extension" to allow an alternative WA and Political Statement to be negotiated. After failing with her WA and Political Statement (not getting it approved by parliament) there would be no point in her staying on as PM to produce another WA that no one wants, so I assume she would have to do the honourable thing and resign (if she did not the Conservative Party could split apart). So I see no point in her staying on as PM after 29th March. 
So either way she is likely to be on her way out quite soon. 
I don't see a general election as being likely, so the next PM is almost certain to be another Conservative.
  So my expectation is that her aim is to press on trying to get the WA through parliament

Theresa May showed her resilience even after two votes of non-confidence, both from the Labour Party (https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/theresa-may-no-confidence-vote-result-jeremy-corbyn-election-brexit-deal-conservative-labour-a8731331.html and https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2019/jan/16/mays-government-survives-no-confidence-vote-after-brexit-defeat)  and her own party (https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-46547246). This is the most time accurate, geographical and situational baseline that can be find on this forecast. Nevertheless, in the next days a unique event will see its final phases, namely Brexit. The day in which it will happen - as analyzed in the forecast about the Article 50's extension - depends basically from Theresa May's ability to draft a program for Brexit which finds the Parliament's agreement. Her success or failure in driving her country into a successful or failing Brexit will determine much of her resilience as Prime Minister. If the Brexit process will be moved after the 1 July, it's unlikely that she will have to face another non-confidence vote, as at least her party can't constitutionally invoke another no-confidence vote until next December (I would give this outcome a 60% probability, in line with the already mentioned forecast). If Brexit will happen before the 1st of July, there's going to be a no-deal Brexit or a Brexit based on a deal the UK Parliament didn't like at all (https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-47547887). In both cases, it is very unlikely that Theresa May will stay in her position (I would say a 10% probability). Adding this last case with the probability of the Brexit deal to be postponed (60%), it's explained why I gave a 70% probabilty to the no answer to the forecast. Let's now move to the cluster of possibilities deriving from the possibility of Thresa May being removed from her office. The UK's electoral system, without explaining the details, basically advantages the big parties, which is the reason why from the very beginning of the elections in this country only two factions basically had an alternance to the government (at the beginning the division was Tories-Whigs, nowadays it's Liberal-Conservatives, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_Kingdom_general_elections). Both the major parties showed their fluctuating trust in Theresa May, but I think it's much more likely that, in case of Theresa May deposed from her office, the opposite party she represent will form a new goverment.
Mrs May has indicated she won't ask for a long extension to Article 50 so long as she is Prime Minister.  So if the EU does not accept her request for a short extension, she may resign.

In attempting such a complex forecast, a tremendous number of factors must be taken into consideration. This is particularly true in regard to the Brexit talks outcome, which is very tied to May’s future and in turn hard to be forecasted. Therefore, let’s start with some general considerations for then narrowing the focus to the given situation.  Firstly, excluding the case where Theresa May dies (hopefully for her), there are three different ways in which the PM might change. These are a) Resignation b) Vote of No Confidence 3) New General Election 
The latter, agreement for a new election, would require two-thirds of parliament (i.e. also the conservative majority shall vote in that sense). This outcome is particularly unlikely, especially before July 1. However, it cannot be completely excluded since calling for a new election, in case of a Brexit disaster, might become a strategic move for the Conservatives to launch a new leadership and obtain a strong mandate in order to deal with the aftermaths of Brexit.  The vote of no confidence wouldn’t be that unlikely if such vote hadn’t already taken place on 12 Dec 2018. Not only in this occasion May survived to the vote, moreover, according to party rules, another vote may only be held after 1 year. Of course, it could be called by the Labour party, however, since they are the minority they would need the consensus of a large section of conservatives which make it extremely unlikely.  Consequently, if the British PM is going to change before July 1 the first option, Resignation, is the one I see as the more likely. It is true that, as data shows, such outcome happened only 3 times since 1940 (out of 16 total PMs in the whole period), making the average of PM stay in charge at 4.9 years. However, the current British political environment, especially due to the Brexit situation, has some peculiarities that cannot be compared with any previous historical pattern. Furthermore, Theresa May has suggested in more the one occasion that she’s not intend to reach the end of the terms (which is in 2022) but that she is willing to stay in charge until the end of Brexit in order to guarantee to the British population the possible outcome possible. Therefore, I see the chances of May resigning closely tied to the result of Brexit. In this regard, as I have already explained in a different forecast, I see as the most likely outcome that Article 50 (and thus Brexit) will be extended by the UK and the European Council before March. However, in this regard, much will depend on the upcoming vote  of March 12. In fact, The House of Commons (the British Parliament) will vote on March 12 the agreement signed by May with Brussels. In case of rejection (very likely), they will hold another vote the day after choosing between a no- deal or a deal Brexit (allowing in case an extension of article 50). Since the terrific consequences of a no deal, I see this outcome by far as the most likely, with May obtaining a new (although still weak) mandate to find an agreement with the EU after March. In doing so, May will try to snatch some concession to return to Westminster with a text more "digestible" for his deputies. This process is likely to end after the summer and for this reason I assess a 70% of chance that there won’t be a new PM before July 1.  Concluding, what remains to be said is assigning the probabilities in case May resigned before July. In this case, I see the possibility of a new Labour PM much more unlikely than of a new Conservative one. Indeed, although according to IPSO’s trends now both the two parties have the 38% of electoral consensus, if May resigned the most likely scenario is the internal election of a new PM among the Conservative Party. The third option, someone of a third party, although never happened after 1945, cannot be completely excluded in the given situation. In fact, in case of a no deal and therefore disastrous consequences for the British Economy, it is not completely excludable the creation of a government of national unity. However, if this outcome is quite unlikely in the long run, it is even more unlikely to happen before July 1.  Sources:
-IPSO trends : https://www.ipsos.com/ipsos-mori/en-uk/voting-intention-great-britain-recent-trends
-List of UK general elections: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_Kingdom_general_elections
-Uk election statistics: https://researchbriefings.parliament.uk/ResearchBriefing/Summary/CBP-7529
-https://www.ilsole24ore.com/art/mondo/2019-03-11/brexit-may-cambia-ancora-idea-cosa-puo-succedere-oggi-14-marzo-103907.shtml?uuid=ABZ3rlcB&refresh_ce=1

While Corbyn is Labour leader is seems very unlikely that Labour would win an election. So any election that took place would probably result in Conservatives and Labour both losing votes and the result being very unpredictable (e.g. low turn out? More votes going to other parties, who may or may not actually win many more seats, a hung parliament?). What would happen in Scotland for example? Scotland voted to Remain, but neither May nor Corbyn has done anything to accommodate Scottish wishes to Remain or at least stay close to the EU, and to keep the EU Freedom of Movement. The SNP is a Remain party in a Remain country, so could pick up some more seats. 

It is possible that Mrs May could resign if she manages to get an EU Withdrawal Deal agree by parliament. Probably that will not happen before 29th March, and if it did A50 would almost certainly need to be extended past 29th March . But as soon as the UK leaves the EU (if it in fact does) Mrs May could resign and the Conservatives would electe a new leader, who would automatically become PM.  My guess is the odds are about 35% that the EU Withdrawal Deal will be passed before 1st July.  Getting the EU Withdrawal Deal is the easy part of Brexit, the hard part will start after parliament approves it and the serious arguments on what type of Future Relationship parliament can agree to. It would need to work for the Irish border or NI will become a problem, and it will need to work for UK manufacturing and food business or the manufacturers will start moving to the EU and the farmers will start going broke (as forecast by the Brexiteers favorite economist Patrick Minford) and the hard line Brexiteers.  Meanwhile  with or without the EU Withdrawal Agreement being passed  by parliament the world economy looks to be turning down, and if it does the UK looks likely to suffer more than most countries because until there is a Future Trade Agreement agreed businesses are unlikely to invest due to uncertainty. Business tends not to stand still, it either invests and moves forward, or it does not and declines (or moves location in the case of Brexit). So it will be interesting to see what happens to the Brexit sentiment if the economy goes into decline. The Leave voters say they are clear that they don't mind being worse off after Brexit, but I am not sure that they have the imagination to picture themselves poorer (or relatively poorer) than the countries that remained in the EU.)

Outside view: Tenure distribution from [1] is 59% likelihood of surviving 1083 days total. Take this as the outside view. Inside view: She has survived so much -- lost a general, lost critical Brexit vote, faced down a no confidence. She appears to be unyielding. Options are death or resignation. Death we can handle with ONS stats [2] since she's 62 she has a very high chance of living >140-ish days (<5%). Resignation is trickier because Brexit is such unknown. Taking the 6 possible outcomes I can foreseee and giving them a 16.6% chance each, I think that only a no-deal Brexit leading to civil hardship would make her consider resignation. I take this at only 6% likelihood total, giving an inside view of 89% likelihood of surviving. Taking the midpoint between inside and outside view (because I'm lazy) gives 74% of survival. To the question of who will replace her: I don't think a party from another party could get a foothold fast enough in this scenario, so I give it the minimum of 1% (I would go lower if I could). Of the last 23 elections (Labour won their first election in 1929) [3], Labour have won 11. Therefore, Labour gets 25% * 48% = 12%, and the Conservatives get the remaining 13%. The UK has thrown itself at the mercy of Brussels over Brexit McGee (2019) January 29, states that: London (CNN)After months of Brexit hot air, the UK's lawmakers have finally given us some idea of what they want. May's so-called plan B was approved by a majority of members of parliament, with some amendments. And it's these amendments which have put flesh on the bones of that plan.
In short, Parliament has told us that it favors sending May back to Brussels to seek concessions on the Northern Ireland backstop. That's the part of the Withdrawal Agreement which aims to prevent the return of border infrastructure between the Republic of Ireland, which will remain in the EU, and Northern Ireland, which will leave with the UK. This has been the single most contentious issue in the ranks of Theresa May's Conservative Party.
In theory, Parliament also ruled out a no-deal Brexit. But it failed to pass any amendment that would have achieved that aim, such as commanding the government to request an extension to the March 29 Brexit deadline, in the event it couldn't pass a deal by the end of February. After two years of this nonsense, it's nothing short of remarkable that the people elected to represent the citizens of the UK still think that this is in their gift (Para. 1-3).
But there's a snag.
The EU has been consistent in saying that the Withdrawal Agreement is done, locked down, not up for renegotiation. It appears not to matter how many times EU officials, diplomatic sources or even May herself tells her rebels this, they seem to think someone is lying. But without the Withdrawal Agreement being reopened, the backstop cannot be changed (Para. 4).
And if the government eventually decides it wants an extension to the Brexit deadline, that must be agreed by the European Council -- the body which comprises the leaders of each member state. It would need to be approved unanimously, meaning any country can veto and, as I'm sure you can see, 28 is a big number.
Unless the UK is willing to concede that May's deal is dead, the EU is unlikely to give the UK more time to continue howling at the moon. As one European diplomatic source recently told me, the EU is loathe to redraft something which has taken 28 nations two years to negotiate in the hope of tweaking it with weeks to go (Para. 4-6). The threat also works for those mortified at the prospect of crashing out without a deal. The Article 50 process -- the official EU exit route -- is nearly over. Without a revocation of Article 50 -- the request of which is in the UK's gift, but is also a total headache -- the default is that the UK leaves the EU on March 29, with or without a deal. Again, back me, or burn the house down (Para. 12). McGee, L. (2019). The UK has thrown itself at the mercy of Brussels over Brexit. CNN. World. UK. 2102 GMT (0502 HKT) January 29, 2019. Labour's failed vote of no confidence has oddly not changed the chances of May lasting until July by much. It never looked very likely that the no confidence vote would pass. Conservatives MPs don't want May to lead them into another election, and unless May resigns they cannot get rid of her. Labour says it will keep trying to call for No Confidence motions, but other parties say they will not support Labour unless something changes, so they are unlikely to be successful. 
So a change of PM before July seems to rely on Mrs May resigning. Any normal person would have already resigned when faced with the public humiliation of her Brexit plans being voted down by a record vote. (I doubt that even she who keeps telling us that Brexit was voted for by more citizens than any other vote in UK history, will want to add that her Brexit deal was rejected by more votes against the government than any other bill in UK history.)
So when this PM seemingly impervious to humiliation will accept that she has failed and does not have the ability to succeed in her self defined version of Brexit, and decides to call it a day is very difficult to forecast. Will it be when she has to withdraw her red lines? Will it be when she is forced to ask for an extension to AS0? Will it be when she has to bin her Brexit deal and go to the EU and ask them to consider an alternative approach?  She already knows a third of Conservatives MPs don't want her as PM. She now knows 48% of MPs don't want her as PM.

At this point , unless Mrs May resigns this is remote: No one else wants the job or to be associated with finding a solution; votes of no confidence are unlikely to succeed and if article 50 is extended (six months) then nothing will actually have changed.

The elections have to be declared minimum 25 business days before 1 July 2019, which effectively frames the question as few separate questions/milestones, an answer to which will require an adjustment of the forecast. 
* Will Theresa May resign? 
* Will UK declare elections before mid-May 2019?
* Who would be the Tory candidate to run against Jeremy Corbyn in the elections in case they will happen?
* What is the main election agenda of each of the candidates (better deal/no deal/second referendum)?  In the meantime it seems that Theresa May refuses to resign and after winning (barely) a vote of confidence, for now the elections are not going to happen before 1 July 2019.

May faced an historic defeat in today's vote on the proposed Brexit deal in today's (15 Jan) vote in the House of Commons, then proposed a confidence vote in the House on 16 Jan. Labour clearly stated during the session that Labour supports a vote of no confidence and a general election.  May's proposal of a confidence vote indicates a high degree of confidence that she will win such a vote. The numbers support this analysis. A no confidence vote requires 2/3 support in the House, or 434 of 650 votes. Labour holds 229. Assuming all non-Conservatives in the House of Commons (HoC) express no confidence, 114 of 330 Conservatives (34.5%) would also have to express no confidence in the PM for May to lose the confidence vote. 
If May were to lose the confidence vote, there would be a 14-day window for the Conservatives to build a new governing coalition. Successfully building a new coalition in the present circumstances would be extremely difficult, and if the Conservatives fail to build a new coalition, a general election would follow. It is impossible to assess the prospects for the Conservatives in a general election, and I expect they prefer not to test the public, having performed poorly in the last general election that they themselves initiated.  Therefore, the best of the set of unattractive options for the Conservatives is to support May in the confidence vote tomorrow, so I assess the probability of May losing the confidence as low (10 - 15%). As a result, the only route I see for May to exit from the PM role by 1 July is via resignation, and her recent comments and positioning lead me to believe that this is marginally less likely today than at my last assessment.

There have been no votes of no confidence before the actual vote on the deal tomorrow, so I am working off these assumptions:
I give the Brexit deal passing tomorrow a probability of 20% (adjusting down from 65% previously, my assumption that there would be a vote of no confidence earlier was wrong). I think if the deal passes, May would would stay. If the deal fails to pass, there are 3 days to come up with the so-called 'Plan B', but I don't think there is much ground to be gained with the EU in that timeframe. So I actually see 'Plan B' failing to pass the Commons at 90% probability, factoring in that there might not even be a vote. What could change that is May threatening the no deal scenario, but I would think that she would face a vote of no confidence soon after that attempt. With plan B rejected, think it is certain that a vote of no confidence that allows for general elections in time before the question closes will follow. Given a vote of no confidence in time, I see a 95% probability of May/the government loosing that vote (in this scenario neither the deal nor Plan B passed). For general elections, I reduced the chance of a PM from neither big parties to 0, and have Labour and Conservatives at 50:50 to win the election, in line with polling data that shows them very close. Following the branches and some arithmetic gives me the forecast.

In order to have a PM from the Labour Party, Labour would need to win a General Election. If there was a General Election today, and Labour ran with the leader it currently has (Corbyn) and with a manifesto that is the same as its current policy (which includes "to deliver Brexit") it difficult to see how it could get more seats in parliament than it has now. Corbyn is seen by those who did not vote Labour in the 2017 as a good example of a 1960s socialist who has had no new ideas in the last 50 years, and is incapable of responding to the world of today. If they had felt Corbyn had anything to offer then they would have voted Labour in 2017. On the other hand there is a growing number of people who voted Labour in 2017 hoping that Corbyn really believed in letting Labour Party Members set the parties policies. but It has become clear that Corbyn's belief in policies set by the people, is as sincerely held by him as it was by Chairman Mao,  Stalin, and Mrs May (i.e.  the "people's" best interests are better served by an all knowing leader, than by taking any notice of the "people") 
The advantage the Conservatives should have if an election were called before July is that presumably they would not be lead by Mrs May, who shares many of the faults that Corbyn has (does not know how to listen and change her policies, or how to lead - by which I mean, the ability to understand an issue, work with experts to formulate a possible solution and then sell that solution to people who had different ideas, in order that the solution is implemented.) In an election of Corbyn vs May the ineptitude of both would cancel each other out and the result could go either way, although Corbyn would have the advantage that as he has never held any government post voters have not had concrete evidence of how bad he would be. May on the other hand has been PM and there is lots of evidence how bad she is. 
So in an election without May the Conservatives could have picked a competent leader with some ideas, which would be a great advantage and could attract wide support and give them a win. But the chances are that the Conservatives could replace May by leader who is as bad as May, and if the Conservative Party Members get their say they would likely pick someone as leader who is a lot worse, and would appeal to no one except the (few) Conservative Party Member. As Conservative MPs are (slightly) more sensible that the Conservative Members they will do all they can to avoid letting the Members pick a new leader. The easiest way to do this is refuse to vote for a General Election.
Therefore my conclusion is that unless May resigns she will remain as PM because the only way to get rid of her by July would be for Conservative MPs to join the opposition in voting her out. They will not want to vote her out in fear of a worse leader (the Leavers fear another Remainer, Remainers fear a Leaver). 
If the Conservatives are forced to elect a new leader then its a 50/50 chance that leader will have very little appeal to the wider electorate.

Having the UK Government lose two votes in two days indicates that Mrs May is losing control. In both cases May was defeated due to senior Conservatives working with opposition parties. In normal circumstances a PM would be expected to resign if this were to happen. 
Mrs May's argument over the last six months is that there is no other plan than to vote for her deal. Today's amendment, that was passed, requires her to present an alternative plan within three (working) days of losing the vote on her Brexit Deal. The expectation is that that vote will occur next Tuesday and that May will lose it. Therefore she would need to present a new plan of action to parliament by 21st Jan. 
There are several things that could happen; (a) May could present a new plan, but a vote of no confidence in the government is called (b) May could herself call for a vote of confidence (c) parliament could present its own (cross party) plan and order May to carry out parliaments wishes. 
A confidence vote seems very likely, but May could win it by agreeing to do what parliament wants. The is big risk for both Labour and Conservatives is that it is very unclear which party would win a general election and its very unclear what the new PM that would inevitably be the result would do. The Conservatives could end up with their Members electing a new PM that could not control the Conservative MPs any better than May. If the Government entered a general election with May remaining as their candidate for PM its difficult to see how the Conservative MPs who had just expressed they had no confidence in her could back her. If May was still PM presumably her manifesto would be "vote Conservative so we can pass the May Deal", but as only around 25% of the public want the May Deal this hardly looks like an election winner. The alternative if May was still PM would be on a manifesto of "vote for the Plan B which I have been telling you for months is not possible". That does not sound like a winner either.
Labour has a similar problem with the additional problem that the polls show them less popular than the Conservatives, so presumably to have a chance of winning an election they would need to change their Brexit policy (to being clearly against Brexit in the eyes of Remainers, but somehow being pro-Brexit in the eyes of Leavers. That seems to leave a very narrow policy option of the Norway+/Common Market 2.0)  e.g. technical outside the EU, but with most of the advantages (and disadvantages) 
https://labourlist.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/Common-Market-2.0.pdf
My guess is that an election will not take place, that A50 will be extended so a revised Withdrawal Agreement can be drawn up, and that a new detailed Political Statement for a new deal (quite likely based on Common Market 2.0) can be drawn up, and then a public vote to chose between Common Market 2.0 or remaining in the EU. (Other option such as No Deal Brexit will not get through parliament, a Canada ++ FT deal will cannot provide the frictionless trade needed to keep the Irish border as it is.

There can be no challenge to Theresa May's Prime Ministership from within her party for another 11 months. According to UK Conservative Party rules there cannot be a leadership challenge during the 12 months following the last spill. However, these are unpredictable times and May could choose to resign within the next 6 months if she came to believe either that it were in the best interests of her country or, that the parliament and her party were rendering her leadership ineffective. It may become increasingly difficult for her to steer the UK through Brexit in a way she believes is best for the country's economic future. Perhaps, she might rather resign the Prime Ministership than be remembered for the short to medium term economic pain that would inevitably follow a no deal Brexit. There's also a chance that the parliament might become so gridlocked that either May asks for another election or has that election forced upon her by the Crown. Her Majesty may also dismiss the May govt if the country become too politically and economically unstable. This happened in Australia in 1975.

Given the YouGov poll released last night and covered in the Sunday papers, I am downgrading the likelihood of both a Labour PM (from 22% to 18%) and a third party PM (from 3% to 2%). The poll was a large sample of 25,000 and the fieldwork was conducted over Christmas in the aftermath of all the uncertainty following the delayed Commons vote on Brexit and the 1922 no confidence vote.  It remains to be seen whether this public support for the Conservatives (as opposed to the Withdrawal Deal) will hold.  The key dynamic is that the Tory party (while divided between MPs' and members' Brexit preference) while risking a parliamentary split, in electoral terms has a much more robust coalition than does Labour (whose MPs, members and voters have more fault lines both between each other and within themselves, regarding Brexit preferences).   With a coalition much more likely to fracure this is why I have downgraded the likelihood of a Labour PM - although not by much, as any general election (if there were to be one) would not solely be about Brexit (which was how the YouGov poll was framed) but about many other issues (e.g. public services) on which Labour has more electorally attractive offers. It seems highly likely that Britain is in for a major political crisis over the next few weeks, as the difficulties of passing the EU Withdrawal Agreement become apparent, along with the associated risk of a disorderly 'no deal' exit.  The major volatility which will follow from this means that I do not want to underprice the likelihood of either possibility of a no confidence vote & Labour government (18%) or a complete breakdown of the two-party system and some shock result of a third party PM (2% - still *very* slim but not impossible - if it were to happen I think it would take longer than until July, but it can't be dismissed it entirely as if there is no deal/2nd ref then the whole infrastructure of parliamentary representation and party configurations will undergo immense strain over the next few months.  As with the Corn Laws, Irish Home Rule and Imperial Preference, it is quite possible for parties wreck themselves on these epoch-defining issues... 'Decades may happen in weeks' as Lenin put it.) I have given a slight uptick to a new Tory PM (from 40% to 41%) as if Theresa May fails to pass a deal (resulting in either a 'no deal' exit or a 2nd referendum) then there will be immense internal pressure for her to stand aside.  Currently this still seems the most likely outcome, as *even if the deal passes* it is likely that she will still be expected to stand down in order that the next stage of the EU negotiations can be taken with a fresh approach and imagination to define Britain's future relationship (rather than the necessary exercise in damage-mitigation that has been the exit negotiations).  I am still very concerned about the political instability we are likely to see across January-March, and it is very possible that events could move much faster than they might usually in 'ordinary' political time. It is difficult to assess this possibility against the 'timing' consideration I identified in yesterday's prediction. My biggest boost though is to Theresa May remaining in power on 1 July (from 35% to 39%), partly because the public are broadly sympathetic to her position (if not her deal), as evidenced by last night's YouGov poll and extreme impatience of the public with the no-confidence vote in December.   The other reason is that my earlier reservations about the length of time it would take to replace her still hold, and it is not yet clear whether the transition to a Tory colleague could be completed by the closing date for this prediction. 2) Vote of No Confidence. I think this is the most likely option. However, it runs into the problem of timescale, there is unlikely to be enough pressure to cause this until very close to March - at which point the timescale is key. It takes about a month to organise a general election so there are two months in which I think a confidence vote is a practical possibility. This is a short timescale given the current dynamics in parliament and it is not quite clear whose interest having a vote of no confidence is in unless it is emergency back covering. Any washout period will also be unusually fraught given that the clock is ticking on Article 50 / its consequences after March. It would require substantial dynamism from the Labour front bench which I think is lacking. I think it is more likely to happen than be won.
3) Agreement for a new general election - another way of putting it is this requires half of Conservative MP's - it's not in their interest - option two is more likely as it only require 34.5% I'd give the outcome of a general election 50:50 but I think it is unusually unlikely.

I have amended this forecast slightly from my original submission a few mins ago, as it was my first one and I wasn't familiar with the format so accidentally submitted early. Rationale: Calling a general election is challenging under the Fixed Terms Parliament Act, which means that a Labour PM by July is not so likely (although I have allowed a certain amount of room for a vote of no-confidence in the event of a no-deal Brexit in March/April, so have given 22%)  For the same reason, the chance for a non-Labour/non-Tory leader is remote given the resurgence in the two parties' votes at the last election.  However, given recent volatility (with the looming probability of serious political turbulence when the Withdrawal Agreement stalls during Jan/Feb) I have given it a rating of 3%: not impossible, but pretty slim. Theresa May's credibility is largely shot among her own party despite having won her no confidence vote in December (which theoretically buys her another 12 months before an internal party challenge).   I strongly suspect that following the delivery (or not) of the EU withdrawal agreement, she will be expected to walk.   Given her humble "I will stay as long as you want me" promise to her backbenchers at the 1922 Committee after the botched 2017 election, I would be surprised if she clung on using the technicality of December's 12-month amnesty as a defence, if her party were to have had enough of her - she can be incredibly obstinate, but that trait is tempered by a deep sense of dutiful service which limits her susceptibility to stubborn power-hunger.  If the parliamentary party no longer wanted her, her character strongly suggests that she would go, allowing for a Tory colleague to take the reigns.  I have given this outcome 40% as the most likely. However MPs can be fickle and a material change in conditions favouring her could change her prospects - albeit currently it is hard to imagine quite how these might happen. Also to be considered is the timing, a Tory leadership contest can be quite a drawn-out affair (Conservative MPs arranging themselves into factions, then gradually narrowing down the contenders field to two acceptable candidates and finally asking every party member to vote on them).  Even if the PM agreed to step down sometime in spring/summer (May for instance), it is quite conceivable that she would still be in post by July 1st, even with a leadership contest ongoing.  I've therefore rated the status quo as a generous 35%, although this will need some adjustments as conditions change.

First, there are three mechanisms for changing PM: 
1) Resignation - this has happened 3 times since 1940 (18.8% of cases, given 16 PMs since then). I view this as quite unlikely, given that it would signal the end of May's political career and would be an exit in extreme duress, destroying her tattered political legacy 
2) Vote of No Confidence: Conservatives held such a vote on 12 Dec 2018, which PM May survived. According to party rules, another vote may only be held after 1 year. A Vote of No Confidence could be triggered by Labour, but given Labour's 229 seats in Parliament (of 650), they would need a minimum of 34.5% of Conservatives to support, assuming all Lib Dems and other party members support the motion, which is highly unlikely. 
3) Agreement for a new general election: this would require 2/3 vote of all MPs - extremely unlikely, given the split in Parliament.  Of the PMs since 1940, the avg PM tenor in office is 4.9 years, w/ a standard deviation of 3.0 years. As of 1 Jul 2019, PM May would have a tenor of ~3.0 years, which carries at ~25.5% probability, given the sample.  As a baseline, also important to consider that in the reference period (from 1940), there have been 8 party changes, on average every 9.8 years. Therefore, I'd consider the baseline probability of a PM change in any ~6 month period of time to be ~ 10% (0.5 years / 4.9 years), w/ a ~5% chance of a party change in the same period (0.5 years / 9.8 years). Finally, it is important to consider there 5 of 16 PMs since 1940 have served under three years, or 26.7%.

In spite of May's tenacity I am finding it difficult to see how she can hold on. There cannot be much chance that she can get her EU Withdrawal bill through parliament (close to 0%) and if she does not surely she should resign (10%). If she does not resign surely Corbyn would call for a Parliamentary Vote of No Confidence (30%) which he might or might not win (50% win). If May won a Parliamentary Vote she could carry on, if not she has a couple of weeks to try and sure up her support before having another vote. So there is only about a 20% chance that May would lose both No Confidence Votes. Even if she does lose both she is still in the game because then there would need to be a General Election and according to the polls the Conservatives could still be the biggest party (not because May is viewed as a good PM, but because Corbyn is not viewed as potentially a good PM). My feeling (based on no data) is that more voters could hold their nose and vote Labour to stop May, than could hold their nose and vote Conservative to get May, but this might be because most people I talk to see Corbyn as useless, but May as dangerous. Corbyn's mistakes could be put right later, May's would last for a generation. 
So my thinking is if May can get past a Parliamentary No Confidence Vote she could hang on. If she loses a Parliamentary No Confidence Vote she might hang on in an election. Although May has got a lot of Conservatives MPs who have no confidence in her, they see that voting No Confidence in the Government (as opposed to voting No Confidence in May as Conservative Leader) would probably mean Corbyn became PM and there was a Labour government. So Conservative MPs are unlikely to vote with the opposition in a Parliamentary No Confidence Vote, An additional reason for Conservatives not to vote No Confidence in the Government is that the outcome could lead to a General Election in which MPs could lose their seats. 
But its difficult to see how May could command day to day control of her party if she fails to get the Withdrawal Agreement through, and difficult to see how she gets thrown out!

I know nothing of the UK Parliament or the election process. Hopefully by the end of this I will know something. To find a baseline I did some research into the United Kingdom Parliament and prime ministers from 1772 to present. From the information I found there have been 76 Prime Ministers. Of those 76, 15 have lost office. 11 coming from a vote of no confidence and 4 coming from resignation. That sets the probability that Theresa May will lose her position from either of those things at .197 probability. Next I looked at when these events happened, were they replaced by someone in their own party, or by someone from another party? of the .197 of position losses .33 went to their own party and .66 to another party. That puts me at a .065 probability it will go to someone in the Conservative Party and .13 probability it will go to someone in the Labour party. These two parties have dominated for decades dating back to at least 1935 and that is questionable to me since I don’t know if there is a difference between the Labour Party and the National Labour Party. For the sake of the math and not believing that anything is impossible I will give the remaining parties and .002 probability of taking the Prime Minister office. To sum up the baseline, 6% - Yes, someone from the Conservative Party
13% - Yes, someone from the Labour Party
1% - Yes, someone from a party other than the Labour or Conservative parties.
80% - No Looking through some of the top comments these numbers seem to be loosely in line with others who may be more educated on this topic. Considering that a vote of no confidence has already taken place, this cannot happen again until beyond the question deadline. That would mean that Theresa May will have to resign. From the information I could find that has only happened 4 times since 1772 which would increase the probability of ‘No’ to .9474. Each time a Prime Minister has resigned they have been replaced by someone of their own party so the probabilities in order become .05, .00, .00 and .95 respectively. Obviously there are a lot of outside factors, but these are good numbers to be aware of going forward. Theresa May has strongly indicated that she will be stepping down before her term ends in 2022, but has been determined to see Brexit through before resigning which is set for March 29, 2019 and a transition period following. The other possibility is the Labour Party could also call for a vote of no confidence and oust her and cause a snap election, but this would also require her own party to essentially bring down their own government.  Right now it seems that the front runners to replace her are Boris Johnson from the conservative party, and Jeremy Corbyn from the Labour Party. It seems to me that Corbyn has more control over the situation than Johnson because he could force a general election which he has shown signs of doing in recent days/weeks.

Theresa May is one hell of a political survivor. She's survived years of very serious criticism, a flubbed slap election in which she decreased her majority, opportunism in her own party, and most recently a no confidence vote. Another no confidence vote cannot take place for a year, so Brexit cannot dethrone her procedurally, she would have to step down. Here are the scenarios I imagine: 1.  The pressure from a bad Brexit deal forces her to step down before Brexit takes place (23%) the replacement is a member of the conservative party.
2. She survives Brexit but the deal is so bad that she is forced to step down, by pure political pressure (5%), the replacement is a member of the conservative party.
3. She survives Brexit but is not able to make an attractive post-Brexit agenda, she is seen as the "Brexit prime minister", and people in her own party force her to step down, the next PM is a conservative (5%)
4. The situation around Brexit forces another snap election, the outcomes for that I predict are:
4a. Given how shallow the Conservative bench is and how well Corbyn energizes his base, Labor wins and Corbyn becomes PM (7%)
4b. The conservatives win and keep May (3%) (who else would they use as the face of the party in an election?)
5. She is able to survive Brexit, hold off her rivals, and make a reasonable plan for a way forward by July 1st (57%)

I think there are multiple stages to consider in this question:
1) votes of no confidence: Labour has tabled a motion against PM May, minor parties a motion against the whole government https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-snp/minor-uk-opposition-parties-table-vote-of-no-confidence-in-government-idUSKBN1OH2L8
2) Brexit deal vote: For simplicity, I assume that a Brexit deal vote has a 65% probability of passing, and assume that if it does not pass May will resign 
3) general election vs existing parliament votes in a new PM: I am assuming there won't be much difference in the probability of scenarios for a) May resigns or b) is forced out of office by a vote of no confidence in herself only. Parliament could vote in a new PM without a general election. They could also decide to call a general election even though they don't have to (I estimate 70% probability for this). If the vote of no confidence in the government as a whole is successful, there has to be a general election.
4) In case of a general election, assuming that it will be a tight race, so 50% Conservatives win, 49% Labour wins, 1% other (see below) (http://ukpollingreport.co.uk/ , thanks @Futureseeker)
5) In either a general election or new PM election case, I am assuming an outside chance of 1% for PM from neither of the big parties. Evaluating the vote of no confidence and Brexit vote stages, I arrived at:
May stays 31%
May out because of failed Brexit deal vote 17%
May out because of vote of no confidence against her 42%
May out because of vote of no confidence against the government 10% Taking the estimates for the general/PM elections gets me to the forecast.
Given the Brexit mess, May's position looks shakier every day, thus > 50% for a replacement. Given that Conservatives hold relative majority the most likely replacement is someone from that party.
